PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Interest Rates
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Our opinion on paper: That ever since the early seventies, high interest rates of staggering magnitude have made a complete mockery of justice, unparalleled in our time.

Resulting in the elimination of employment on a vast scale, in every phase of production causing house ejections, with mind effects and mental disturbances, leading to interrupted education, road toll and social disruption.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your House urge politicians of all parties to nationally unite for the return of Justice by using the powers vested in them to immediately and drastically reduce these destructive interest rates. Further and to this end a conscience vote is essential, if justice is to be served.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 38 citizens), Button (from 48 citizens), Harradine (from 68 citizens), Lewis (from 93 citizens) and Robertson (from 258 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Crowley (from 36 citizens) and Giles (from 128 citizens).

TALK.START.PARA: —I again remind honourable senators that the number of questions which can be asked during any Question Time is determined by the length of questions and the length of answers. To enable more questions to be asked, co- operation must be forthcoming from both sides of the chamber.

—(Western Australia-Leader of the Opposition)-by leave-Mr President, I thank you for your immediate attention to the matter which was raised in the Senate. —This very short question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: Do the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions agree that increases in the social wage will be reflected in a moderation of wage demands? Do a number of measures in last Thursday's mini- Budget mean an effective decrease in the social wage, a decrease costed by many commentators at $8 to $10 per week? How does the Government intend to deal with the prospective exacerbation of wage demands to which such increases in the social wage would give rise?

—On the assumption that the calculations to which Senator Chaney referred about the effect of the economic statement last week are correct, I suggest that the question of the social wage has to be seen in the context of the economic statement of last week and the forthcoming Budget. It is not the intention of the Government to have its prices and incomes policy in full place until later this year, and the combined effects of the statement and the Budget will have to be taken into account in assessing the question of the social wage. I was asked, in the earlier part of the question, whether the Government and the ACTU agree on the importance of the social wage to the prices and incomes policy , and the answer to that question is yes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Leader of the Government for his answer, but ask: Is it not a fact that the Government will have to assert a view on wages before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission before the August Budget and, in those circumstances, it will need to have a view on the point raised which does not take into account the combined effect of the two, because the Budget will not be available to us? I ask him, therefore: What view has the Government adopted with respect to the social wage at this stage when it has all the information that can be available to it before it goes to the Arbitration Commission?

—It is the Government's view that there should be no national wage hearing before the middle of this year. The Government has also indicated that, in the latter half of this year, it would see a 3 to 4 per cent increase in wages as being consistent with its overall economic policy. The question of the way in which the national wage case is dealt with is currently being considered in a series of conferences before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission President, Sir John Moore. The Government will be putting its view there. There have been full and recent consultations with the ACTU following the economic statement of Thursday of last week. These matters have been discussed and will be the subject of further discussion with that organisation.

—I understand that the Minister for Social Security has received submissions made in the time of the previous Government to provide additional funding for an early intervention program in South Australia to assist Down's syndrome children. In view of the anxiety of the parents of these children and the need to help, as expressed in many representations to the Government and the previous Government by myself and others, I ask the Minister whether he has made a decision on this matter.

—The Government did receive a submission from an organisation called Down's Syndrome Incorporated in South Australia which is made up of a small group of parents of Down's syndrome children and specialists who deal with those children in an attempt to improve the method whereby children with Down's syndrome can be kept at home and enabled to utilise what abilities they have to the maximum without having to go into institutions. As a result of such submissions, the Government decided to increase the funding to this organisation to the extent of about $30,000 to enable this program to continue not only for the children and the parents who are involved in the program but also so that the experience and information which they gain can be handed on to other parents and organisations dealing with Down's syndrome in our community generally. The result of this submission and of this increase in funding, I believe, will be an expansion of a worthwhile program which will be to the benefit of all parents and all children in this situation in Australia.

—I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to his often quoted justification for preventing the development of Australia's uranium, namely, that there is presently a lack of markets for uranium. Can the Minister say that, if companies can get contracts at the prices set by the previous Government, the Government will allow the development of uranium projects such as Honeymoon, Jabiluka, Koongarra and Yeelirrie?

—I have not been saying that there is a lack of markets for uranium . What I have been saying is that I do not believe that any Australian producer has signed or can sign a contract at prices which would have been acceptable to the previous Government.
—I am saying 'if they do that'.
—All right. I am going on. I have also stated, of course, that, indeed, a contract was rejected by the previous Government for just those reasons: The pricing arrangements were not satisfactory.
—No.

—A contract was rejected by the previous Government because the pricing arrangements were not satisfactory. It was at about the end of last year ; I am not sure of the precise date. That of course confirms the accuracy of the view that the Government has taken of the state of the world market. As to the hypothetical question posed by Senator Messner that some company may be able, at some unspecified time, to produce a contract with pricing arrangements which would have been acceptable to the previous Government, should that happen-I believe that is unlikely-as I have said before, that will be considered by the Government in the light of the Australian Labor Party's policy on waste disposal , nuclear proliferation and also the commercial aspects.

—Is the Attorney-General aware that peanut growers in Queensland are arming themselves in response to raids by members of the Peanut Marketing Board who are invoking 57-year-old legislation which empowers them to make such raids if they suspect that peanuts are being kept on the premises? Is he aware that this legislation gives the Board power to investigate, enter private homes, search, apprehend, confiscate crops and documents without compensation and halt the transport of peanuts from individual farms? As the legislation is being revived in an attempt to restore a monopoly market for the Board and prevent peanut farmers selling their product on an interstate market, does the Attorney- General consider that these measures are in direct contravention of section 92 of the Constitution which states emphatically that intercourse amongst the States shall be absolutely free? If so, what action can the Commonwealth Government take to uphold the principles of free enterprise in relation to Queensland's peanut farmers and avert any possible bloodshed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to certain media reports suggesting that the position is as suggested in the honourable senator's question. I understand that powers of the nature referred to by the honourable senator are conferred by or under the Primary Producers Organisation and Marketing Acts in Queensland in relation to the investigation of contraventions of the Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable senator will appreciate that it is not the practice nor is it appropriate under Standing Orders for me to provide legal advice or opinions in relation to this or any other matter. The Queensland Act in question and the powers conferred under it would need to be construed, of course, in light of the constraints on State legislative power which are imposed by section 92 of the Constitution. If Queensland peanut farmers do consider that the Queensland Act is being administered in a manner inconsistent with the requirements of the Act or of section 92 of the Constitution they should seek appropriate relief through the judicial processes available to them.

My preference so far as the reform of section 92 is concerned has been stated often enough and is simply this: It ought to be repealed entirely or at least amended so that it applies only to discriminatory laws or executive acts directed to the impairment of freedom of trade, commerce and intercourse among the States and the Territories.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware that a justice of the Family Court of Australia in Melbourne named Frederico is reported to have refused to hear a case because the barrister, a woman, was wearing slacks instead of what the judge deemed to be appropriate female gear? Is it true that that barrister, who is the only female member of the council of the Law Institute of Victoria, was representing a person who had travelled at some expense from Sydney for the case which had to be adjourned because of the judge's decision? I ask the Attorney- General whether he considers consistent with civil liberties the following statement of the judge:

QUESTION.PARA: I am not even going to hear you on the question of whether or not I should hear you. This case is adjourned.

Does the Attorney-General consider that a person who so blatantly discriminates against another person is a fit and proper person to administer justice in a Federal court? If not, will the Attorney take steps which could bring about the transfer of this person to another jurisdiction where his shameful bias and discrimination will not affect the proper administration of justice?

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be appreciated by Senator Chipp and other honourable senators that it is not the practice of this Government, or indeed of any Australian Labor Party government in Australia, to seek to interfere in any way with the conduct by members of the judiciary of their courts. Certainly under those circumstances I would not seek in any way directly to raise the matter with the judge in question or to take any action of the kind that has been so robustly suggested by Senator Chipp.
—It is a serious question.

—It will get a serious answer, Senator Chipp. It has been quite serious so far. Nonetheless, it does appear that an error of judgment may have been made in this matter by the judge in question. On the next occasion that I have-they arise quite often-to discuss matters affecting the Family Court of Australia with Chief Judge Evatt I will raise with her the standards of dress propriety that are being applied in that court.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the public gallery, behind Government senators, of former Senator Poyser of Victoria. I am sure all honourable senators join me in welcoming Mr Poyser back to Canberra.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been drawn to a report of a meeting of the Independent Teachers Federation of Australia in Perth over the weekend at which a move to set up a national committee to sponsor the introduction of peace studies in Australian schools was adopted unanimously? State school teachers having previously endorsed such studies, can the Minister indicate the Government's likely response to submissions seeking funding for the development of studies of peace and the peaceful resolution of conflict?

—I did notice the item in the media over the weekend. Like many honourable senators, I was pleased to see that the Independent Teachers Federation believes that the study of the resolution of conflict should become an important part of the school curriculum. As Senator Giles will be aware, the setting of curriculum in schools is, by and large, a matter for State education authorities and even now in many States a matter for the local school community. The Government in principle agrees with the decentralisation of curriculum development in this fashion, but recognises also that there is a need for national leadership and a national role in curriculum development. The previous Government of course disbanded the national Curriculum Development Centre, and since that time there has been no proper national role for curriculum. It is the intention of this Government to restore a national curriculum function. Once that is restored-I expect that that will be the case shortly-resolutions, such as the very constructive and forward looking resolution of the Independent Teachers Federation, can be forwarded to the appropriate body and, I expect, responded to in a favourable manner.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the prediction by the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr Hurford, on this morning's Australian Broadcasting Commission news that home loan interest rates are likely to fall as a result of the mini-Budget? Does Senator Button agree with his colleague? If he does, will he indicate, for the benefit of hundreds of thousands of Australians facing higher weekly repayments following the loss of the tax rebate, when such downward movement is likely and its extent?
—I am not aware of the statement made by Mr Hurford. I will contact the Minister and try to provide an answer as quickly as possible.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of recent comments by General Motors-Holden's Ltd about the existing passenger motor vehicle policy, particularly regarding export facilitation and light commercial vehicles? Are the company's comments in line with the difficulties it is now facing with 1,500 jobs to go from the Woodville plant in my State of South Australia and 1,300 to go in Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much aware of recent comments made by General Motors about the state of the passenger motor vehicle industry and about passenger motor vehicle policy. The Government is very concerned at the impact of the company's decisions on social policy and on particular regions. I understand the point of the question to be to elicit what attitude the Government takes to General Motors-Holden's comments about increased competition from imports of light commercial vehicles and the importance to the company's future of the export facilitation scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of assistance to the industry will be considered in mid-June when the Automotive Industry Advisory Council meets. Of course, there are a number of interests and different points of view to be considered about the sort of package of assistance which should be made available to the industry. I do not in any sense want to pre-empt those discussions except to say that the problems of General Motors, in my view, cannot be attributed to the question of the existing motor vehicle policy in relation to the imports of light commercial vehicles, nor can they be considered as a responsibility of the present state of the export facilitation scheme. However, we will have the opportunity to discuss these matters with the company at the Automotive Industry Advisory Council in June. We hope that a solution to those problems can then be reached.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs review a decision taken early this year by me, as her predecessor, to refuse to allow a substantial amount of Commonwealth transition education funding to be given to the notorious Victorian radio station 3CR? Is this the same radio station which promotes extremist views and which, as recently as last Sunday week, disseminated information about Australian security organisations? Does the decision that it was not appropriate for Commonwealth education funds to be used to support this radio station still stand?

—The decision certainly still stands. As I recall, the process of having the decision taken by my predecessor, Senator Peter Baume, reversed involved an acceptance by me of the recommendations of the State Education Minister in Victoria. The decision in respect of this transition program-I understand it is a program allowing young people at the school leaving stage to learn about the operation of a radio station-was taken in the same way that any other program decision is made; that is, the State Minister of Education agrees that certain training or transition programs are within the guidelines of the Commonwealth funded transition program. In this case Mr Fordham, the State Minister, decided that the program was within the guidelines. I saw no reason not to accept the decision of the Victorian Minister of Education with regard to the training opportunities being afforded under this program. I think it is absolutely crucial to distinguish between the access that the young people in question have, I presume, to learning some of the technical side of broadcasting and the operation of a radio station and some of the program material that that radio station broadcasts. It seems to me that the two are entirely different. I would very much doubt that the transition students would have any editorial role in determining program material. Although I remember that there has been a fairly turbulent history with regard to some program material broadcast by 3CR, I think it is entirely wrong and unreasonable for Senator Baume to suggest that, because 3CR as a community access station broadcasts some material that he and, I acknowledge, a sizable proportion of the community have had some objection to in terms of its content, that radio station which, after all, is supported to some extent by the Commonwealth, should not be able to offer training facilities to young persons. But in any case, I saw no reason to oppose the decision to accredit 3CR's training scheme under the training program taken by the Victorian Minister of Education.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I do not think the Minister answered one part of my question. I had taken a decision, as former Minister for Education, that the Victorian Minister's recommendation should not be acceded to and I had so informed him. I ask the Minister again: Has she taken action to overturn that decision and thereby make funding available to radio station 3CR?

—I do not know where Senator Baume was for the last two minutes or so. I answered the question, yes. I have taken action to overturn the decision of my predecessor, Senator Baume. That decision was to reject the decision of the Victorian Minister of Education. I have overturned that decision. I have accepted the decision of the Victorian Minister of Education and in the last couple of minutes I explained my reason for doing so.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that surgeons in some States are charging and receiving payment for operations such as appendicectomies when those operations are not being performed by surgeons and when, in some cases, the surgeons are not present at the operation? Is this practice legal? Will the Government investigate this practice with a view to stopping what seems to be an immoral, if not illegal, practice?

—In answer to the second part of the honourable senator's question I, as a bush GP, would not be willing to give a legal opinion in this place when some of the bush lawyers in this place are not allowed to. However, as the honourable senator says, if the practice is not illegal it should be, and it is certainly immoral. It has certainly been drawn to my attention that in some States surgeons have been charging for operations such as appendicectomies when all they have done is to give the registrar the okay over the phone to go ahead with that procedure, and they have not even turned up for the operation. I understand that this practice is sometimes justified by the statement of the surgeons that they are receiving the money from the medical benefits funds and that the money then goes into some travel or study fund in the hospital in which they work. I do not approve of this procedure, if it occurs. I certainly believe that the Department of Health should look into it. I believe that the Government will agree with me. I will refer that question to the Minister for Health--
—To the Public Accounts Committee.
—I dare say, as Senator Georges says, it might end up before the Public Accounts Committee of this Parliament. We will see whether this matter is occurring and what we can do about it if it is.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce been drawn to a statement made by the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, to the annual conference of the Institution of Engineers held on 22 April 1983? The Minister stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Australian's declining employment in manufacturing is permanent, irreversible and structural. In my view it is not temporary or to be rectified by tariffs, wage freezes, bounties, quotas or other fiscal measures.
Does that statement represent the view of the Minister for Industry and Commerce ? If not, in what way does the Minister differ from his junior colleague?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read the statement made by the Minister for Science and Technology.
—I will send you a copy.

—There is no need for the honourable senator to send me a copy; I am quite sure that the Minister will have sent me several. But I am asked a question about whether I agree with the view of the Minister for Science and Technology that the decline in manufacturing employment is permanent and irreversible.
—And cannot be rectified by tariffs, wage freezes, bounties, quotas or other measures.

—Yes, that was the second part. With regard to the first part of the question, my general answer is yes. The experiences of the manufacturing industry in Australia in the last 15 years show that manufacturing employment has declined from approximately 27 per cent of total employment to something in the order of 18 per cent of total employment. A number of people who would be more expert than I in these matters suggest that by the turn of the century manufacturing employment in Australia, as we traditionally know it, will probably decline to about 12 per cent of total employment. I am unable to say whether that view is correct. I turn now to the part of the question which asked whether that employment decline can be rectified or reversed by tariffs, quotas and other protective devices. I believe that, in part, the rapidity of the decline can be rectified by those protective measures. Certainly, the social cost and the cost to capital in the form of investment can be alleviated by those sorts of measures. I cannot take the answer any further than that.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. Quite obviously, the supplementary question is: Will the Government adhere to the policy promise that protection will not be lowered in any way during the current recession?
—Yes, other than any reduction which is already planned by particular industry schemes; that is, phasing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What is the Government's reaction to the destructive bombing raid on the Mozambique capital of Maputo by the South African Air Force? Does the Government agree with the South African Government that the raid was justified following the bombing of the South African Air Force headquarters in Pretoria?

—The Government totally opposes the political system of apartheid in South Africa and is concerned about the loss of lives of South African citizens, irrespective of race, which has resulted from violence in that country . The Government condemns the use of indiscriminate violence as a means of changing the South African Government's political system and also, of course, totally condemns the raid by the South African Air Force which resulted in the bombing of what is believed to be the headquarters of the South African National Congress in the capital of Mozambique, Maputo. The Australian Government considers that the latest attack in Mozambique, like earlier attacks launched by South Africa into neighbouring countries, does nothing to solve the root causes of the problems in southern Africa and has condemned this latest use by South Africa of its Air Force to attack a sovereign neighbouring country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Does the Minister agree with his colleague the Minister for Resources and Energy that the 'Labor Party both in opposition and in government has made it perfectly clear that it believes that there must be a decline in real wages as an essential component of a package for economic recovery'? If the Minister agrees, I ask whether he can tell my why, in the accord made between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australian Labor Party, it was agreed:

QUESTION.PARA: To protect the purchasing power of wages and salaries the adoption of a system of full cost of living adjustments will be strongly supported in tripartite consultations and before industrial tribunals.

Further, does this paragraph of the accord explain the recent decision of the ACTU to seek full consumer price index increases for 1983? Finally, will the Minister tell us what is the current Government policy on the indexation of wages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what Senator Walsh said about-
—I just quoted it to you.
—I know you just quoted it to me but you may well have quoted it out of context.
—It is in Hansard, page 177.
—Order! Senator Lewis, you have asked your question.

—The point that I perhaps have to make to Senator Lewis is that this is not a higher school certificate examination. This is Question Time. I will not comment on statements made by my colleagues on particular issues which may well have been taken out of context. But the fact of the matter is that there has been a decline in real wages in recent months in this country. The point of your question, as I understand it, Senator, was to ask whether the Labor Party agrees with that as a continuing process. You moved from that part of the question to the accord which deals with the maintenance of the real value of wages over time. If we are talking about quoting, Senator, I am quoting in using that expression 'over time'.
—Order! I ask the Leader of the Government to direct his answer through the Chair.
—Thank you, Mr President. I am indebted for the assistance of the Chair.
—It might shorten things.

—The answer is yes, the Government believes that, as soon as we are able to initiate economic recovery in this country, it will be most important in terms of sustaining that recovery that there be a fair share of its proceeds throughout the community. If that is not so, the recovery will not ultimately succeed.

ANSWER.PARA: So, if the second part of the question, as I interpret it, was whether we believe that wages should be adjusted when the prices and incomes policy is fully in place in accordance with changes in the consumer price index, whether it be done yearly, half-yearly or quarterly, the answer is yes. The mechanism for adjusting wages on that basis will be determined by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child, Article 10, states:

QUESTION.PARA: The child shall be protected from practices which may foster racial, religious and any other form of discrimination. Recognising that it is people, represented by Governments which are responsible for the decisions to participate in armaments and war, it is essential that children are afforded the right to learn about peaceful resolutions of conflict and creative attitudes to common security.
In Tasmania Dr Margaret Bailey--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable senator to direct her question.

—I am directing it now. Dr Margaret Bailey has been instrumental in initiating seminars and discussions on education for peace. In New South Wales the Australian International School held a conference in October 1981. I ask the Minister--

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The honourable senator has been once stopped by you and has had her attention drawn to the need to ask a question. She has persisted for a considerable time and I ask you to disallow the question and to move on to another question.
—I ask the honourable senator to restrict her remarks to a question to the Minister.

—Thank you, Mr President. I ask the Minister: Will she investigate the establishment of a curriculum unit for peace education which will relate to and permeate the curriculum? Will she consider the provision of enabling funding to teachers who are using initiatives for peace studies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hearn's question is really along the same lines as the question previously asked today by Senator Giles. It again draws attention to a great defect in the educational processes in Australia. Through those processes a great deal of time is spent teaching students about wars and various militaristic enterprises. There is very little generally in the curriculum throughout Australia which would encourage young people to leave school with some concept that peace is a realisable aim.

ANSWER.PARA: I repeat to Senator Hearn what I said to Senator Giles: It is the intention of this Government, in contrast to the previous Government, to re-establish a national curriculum function. The role of that national curriculum body will be to take up issues of national, and indeed in this case international, significance such as the development of peace and resolution of conflict studies and materials suitable for use in schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy once more to his colleague Mr Keating's statement of 21 April last year that, should agreement with the States on the introduction of a resources rental tax fail, the Commonwealth would resort to coercion through reducing States grants. In view of the Minister's repeated failure to clarify the issue, I ask him to say without evasion or equivocation whether he stands by Mr Keating's statement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered this question at least twice last week. I am familiar with the statement that Mr Keating has made. I still hope that the States will see common sense and reason and agree with the proposals that are being put to them. I repeat: If as a result of inability in the present depressed market conditions high cost mines are not able to pay the substantial production-type taxes which are now levied on them by State governments and which we want to replace with a profit-related tax, and if those mines have to close because of those State government charges, the political odium for those closures will rest with the State governments which caused them. I hope that for that reason, if not for more intellectual and principled reasons, the State governments will agree to change the tax system in the way that we envisage.

ANSWER.PARA: As for Mr Keating's statement, it is at all times correct that the bottom line of State government revenues is written by the Commonwealth. That has been the case ever since 1942 or thereabouts. There is nothing new about that. At least at this stage the Government is not threatening, however, to withdraw funds from States in a punitive way if they decline to agree with the sorts of policies on mineral industry taxation which this Government wants. I might add that that is somewhat of a contrast to not just the intentions but also the actions of the previous Federal Government, which gave the Victorian Government a healthy dose of Fraser Liberal Party style centralism when that Government introduced a taxing measure which it did not like. The Victorian Government was rewarded with a stiff dose of Liberal Party Fraser style Canberra centralism. If the Government at some subsequent stage should decide-I am not forecasting that this will happen-to proceed in the way that Senator Scott described, with coercion, the word I think he used, it would be following in a milder way the example set and precedent established by the previous Government in its dealings with Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen an article headed 'Court finds Tubemakers guilty of WA steel ''fix'' ' which appeared in yesterday's Australian Financial Review? Did the article report that companies associated with the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, namely, Steel Supplies (Aust) Pty Ltd and Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, and a Steel Supplies director, Mr Barry Neil Bint, have been convicted by Mr Justice Toohey under section 45 of the Trade Practices Act of 'illegally attempting to control steel prices in Western Australia'? Is the Minister able to say how much these price fixing activities have cost consumers in Western Australia? Will the Government consider amending trade practices law to enable injured consumers to take a class action against offenders of this type?

—I did see the newspaper reference to the Tubemakers case yesterday but I have not yet seen a more detailed report of the decision in that case. I am certainly not in a position at this stage to advise the honourable senator as to how much the price fixing activities in question may have cost consumers.
—It was an attempt that they were convicted of. They had not done it.

—Maybe that is the appropriate explanation. Had they done it there may have been some quantifiable cost involved which it may be possible for me to ascertain, that presumably being the foundation of the proceeding that was then taken. If I can get further information I will advise the honourable senator accordingly. As to the operation of trade practices law in this area, Part IV of the Trade Practices Act, the restrictive practices aspect, is under active review at the moment in my Department, in consultation with the Trade Practices Commission. The consumer protection provisions in Part V of the Act are equally under active review in the portfolio of my colleague the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Indeed, a paper on aspects of that area has been put out recently. As to the question of class actions for injured consumers , that is a matter that the Government is proposing to give detailed consideration to in the context of the final report of the Law Reform Commission on this matter which is anticipated, I think, later this year.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the cost of basic health insurance is at present a component of the consumer price index? Is it correct that, in the event of Medicare coming into operation, this component will be removed, thereby reducing the CPI by several percentage points? If this is the case, can the Minister say what effect this is likely to have on increases in pensions since they are adjusted twice a year according to the CPI?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is my understanding that, with the way the CPI is at present calculated, the introduction of the Medicare scheme or a universal health insurance scheme will in fact result in a reduction in the level of the CPI as it is calculated now. This, of course, will affect increases in pensions as they are calculated now under the automatic indexation scheme. But as the honourable senator would know, the present Government takes as its parameter for the level of pensions a percentage of average weekly earnings. We intend, over the whole period of this Governments if economic conditions allow as I am sure they will, to increase pensions as a percentage of average weekly earnings. If by increasing pensions in line with CPI increases we do not reach that parameter , we will adjust pensions so that the situation is dealt in that way.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the honourable senator of what happened in the past. In 1975 pensions had almost reached 25 per cent-they were about 24.5 per cent-of average weekly earnings. Since then they have been automatically indexed twice a year except for the year when the then Government unwisely omitted one indexation. But as a result of pressures from the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and pensioners ' organisations, the then Government restored that increase. Despite the fact that over that time pensions have been increased in line with CPI increases twice a year, their value has dropped to 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. I think this raises an important point: I believe and I have always believed it to be wrong to fix pensions just by CPI increases because CPI increases vary with the state of the economy and the level of productivity in the community. I think we have to fix a parameter, be it average weekly earnings or some other parameter, so that the true level of pensions relates to some recognisable and true value of the wages of other people in the community. For that reason we will watch the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Finance been drawn to a report in today's Australian newspaper containing criticisms of the Government's legislation to recover tax avoided in bottom-of- the-harbour schemes? What substance is there to these criticisms? In particular, has the Minister received representations from the building industry with regard to withholding tax? What is the Minister's response to these representations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to the last part of Senator Robert Ray's question-that is, the part concerning withholding tax and representations from the building industry-I will ask the Minister for Finance for an answer. In regard to the first part of the question, yes I have seen a particularly ill-informed news report in the Australian newspaper today about the tax legislation introduced by Mr Dawkins, the Minister for Finance, I think on Thursday of last week. If we eliminate the possibility of malevolence, it is clear that the journalist concerned has been snowed by tax dodgers and their accomplices with a series of false assertions. I will not detail all the assertions but I will mention at least two.

ANSWER.PARA: It is stated in the Australian report that the legislation does not apply to public companies. Under this legislation, vendors who sold shares to what are colloquially known as bottom-of-the-harbour operators will be forced to pay the personal tax evaded by the illicit sales in addition to the company tax which was payable, or at least in most cases was payable, under legislation passed by the previous Government. The Australian asserts that that will apply to private companies but not to public companies. That is quite wrong, with one minor exception, namely, that for certain non-profit and government-controlled companies the legislation does not trace a deemed dividend to individuals, if any, behind the company. The second point with which I will deal is that it is asserted in the Australian that personal tax on deemed dividends will be payable in cases where vendors are also liable under the existing legislation for unpaid Division 7 tax. That also is totally false. If personal tax becomes payable under the proposed amendments the Division 7 tax liability is specifically eliminated, and any such tax paid will be refunded to the persons who paid it.

There are other matters in that report which are, I suppose, to some extent matters of opinion and not outright misstatements of fact. They are opinions which I will not debate at this stage but which can be also easily scuttled. I say in closing that I believe it is about time the Press accepted its responsibility. If it is going to write stories like that, then, instead of-as I presume happened in this case-ringing some accountants who have been helping tax dodgers to escape with billions of dollars in recent years and imposing billions of dollars in burdens upon other honest taxpayers, I believe it is a social responsibility of the journalists concerned to get definitive and accurate information from the proper authorities instead of listening to the bleatings of tax dodgers and their agents.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of his public endorsement, as reported in the Tasmanian newspapers on 2 March, of reports that an American company is negotiating to establish a computer manufacturing plant employing 300 people in Tasmania, will the Minister inform the Senate of, firstly, the name of the company, secondly, what evidence he possesses of the company's bona fides, thirdly, the amount of financial support the company is seeking and, finally, the amount of money the Federal Government is prepared to provide in view of the fact that he was reported as stating three days before the election that the Government would encourage such a development and support it financially?

—Senator Walters refers to a public statement attributed to me in the Tasmanian Press on 2 March. As I recall, we were in Opposition then and it sounds highly likely. The statement was made by me. It concerned a United States company which had made inquiries through a Melbourne agent about the possibility of investing in a computer software plant and also manufacturing some computer hardware. I am not able to tell the honourable senator the precise name of the company; I am not even sure I remember it at this stage. I was asked to keep it confidential. I should inform the honourable senator that I have been in correspondence with the Minister for Industry and Small Business in Tasmania regarding this matter and that he has made similar inquiries of me. The Melbourne agents of the company I mentioned have written to the Tasmanian Government about this matter. There was some confusion because the agents of the company wrote to the Premier's office and for some reason which has not been explained to me the letter did not reach the Minister for Industry for some time after it arrived at the Premier's office. I have no explanation at all of that, but it seems to be a matter of fact from my correspondence with the Tasmanian Minister for Industry. I am currently in the process of trying to obtain some further information for the Tasmanian Minister. As soon as I do, I will provide it to him. I think the honourable senator will appreciate that as confidentiality has been requested by the company concerned it would be improper for me to mention in the Senate the name of the principal company. However, I repeat that if it is the intention of that company to establish itself in Tasmania the Federal Government will certainly examine in a constructive way what financial assistance can be given to it to assist that process.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I can perhaps understand the need to maintain the confidentiality of the name of the company, but will Senator Button please answer the rest of the question that I asked him? What evidence does he possess of the company's bona fides? What amount of financial support is the company seeking? What amount of money is the Federal Government prepared to provide in view of the fact that the Minister said that he would encourage such development and support it financially?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It follows, I would have thought as night follows day, that if the company has no bona fides, as is implicit in the first part of the question, the Federal Government would not have pledged a particular amount of money to it . Indeed it would be ridiculous to do so until such time as there is a firm proposition from the company concerned. I do not know what amount the company is seeking. That would depend very much on the place where it proposes to site its activities, the extent of the plant required and so on. Those questions would properly be addressed at that time.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as the bona fides of the company are concerned, I understand it to be a company of world repute and one which has manufacturing operations in a number of countries in the world. Whether this is a fair dinkum-if I may use that expression-inquiry in relation to Tasmania, I am unable to say but I am sure that the Minister for Industry and Small Business will investigate that question and provide the honourable senator with the answer as soon as he can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 22 February this year, 14 governments signed a pledge to the world disarmament campaign launched last June at the United Nations General Assembly. I ask the Minister: Why is Australia's name not on the list of signatories? What active measures is Australia presently taking in the United Nations and elsewhere to promote disarmament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the information available to me, I cannot answer the first part of the question but I will certainly seek an early opportunity to do so and give a considered Government response, including our current attitude. However, there are a number of initiatives which the Government is either undertaking or planning in relation to the whole international consideration of arms control and disarmament issues. We are certainly giving consideration to the appointment of an ambassador whose sole responsibility would be for disarmament and arms control matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Another step that we have taken is to express a very active protest against the continuation of French nuclear tests in the Pacific. Associated with that is our very active support, which we will be pursuing particularly at the South Pacific Forum Conference to be held in August this year in Canberra, for the concept of a South Pacific nuclear free zone. Whether that concept of nuclear free zones can be expanded beyond this narrow regional context is also being actively considered. In that respect we have accepted, as a government, the invitation to join the United Nations Secretary-General's Nuclear Weapon-Free Zone Study Group which is to report to the 1984 General Assembly.

Australia has expressed its keen support for the international negotiations that are now proceeding in fits and starts for a nuclear freeze followed, hopefully, by negotiated arms reductions. That is wholly in accord with our general approach as a government to regional and general international agreement for arms control and disarmament and is certainly an exercise to which we as a government will be giving such active support as we can in international forums.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Those people are to be removed from the gallery.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General and is not on the subject on which he has just answered. Is it a fact that the Government has now backed away from its intention to hold a referendum on the constitutional alteration proposals on 20 August? If that is the case, what are its reasons, or did it just seem a good idea at that time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will endeavour to focus on the matter raised by Senator Durack. The situation is, as I have publicly announced, purely a function of the Government's review of its legislative program. The parliamentary business committee of Cabinet met this morning to review that program. It became apparent that the pressure of business is now such that a full debate on the referendum Bills in both Houses of the Parliament is simply not possible in the time available. As Senator Durack will be well aware, the second reading debate in the Senate is only very partially complete at the moment and the House of Representatives is due to rise at the end of this week.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the need to ensure that referendum proposals attract the maximum possible consensus, the Government really does not believe that it would be altogether consistent with that objective for debate-if not in this chamber, at least in the House of Representatives-to be gagged, guillotined or otherwise unduly curtailed in order to get the Bills through. The situation, accordingly, is that the party has decided to delay further consideration of these Bills until after Parliament resumes. Further consideration will be given at that time by the Government to the timing of the referendums themselves.

The postponement, to this extent, will also give the Government an opportunity to consult further with the Opposition, if it is demonstrating a willingness to be consulted on these matters, and enable the Commonwealth to consult more closely with the States-particularly in the context of the forthcoming Premiers Conference-again with a view to maximising the chances of a consensus approach to these very important machinery proposals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs been approached in relation to a dispute concerning cleaning services at the University of Queensland? If so, is the Minister able to advise whether the Commonwealth Government can do anything to resolve the dispute?

—I have not been approached on this matter and I do not expect that I will be. As Senator Colston will know, the management of industrial and staffing matters within universities is a matter for the universities themselves . I hope that the matter will be resolved-I am sure it will be-without any intervention by the Commonwealth Minister.

—In light of the very considerable interest in the question of disarmament on the part of Government senators, I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce: Will the Government now proceed to sell the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo?

—The interest displayed in disarmament here today and indeed in questions from the Opposition was in the question of nuclear disarmament. The Bendigo Ordnance Factory does not make nuclear weapons and it will not be sold by the present Government.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether he recalls stating in the Senate on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: I am advised that it is the Government's intention to construct the Alice Springs to Darwin railway as part of its long-standing commitment to the completion of an all-weather standard gauge connection between Adelaide and Darwin. . . . I recall that the then shadow Minister for Transport Mr Morris, who is now the Minister, made a commitment during the election campaign in February that a Labor government would continue construction of the line between Alice Springs and Darwin, with a suggested target date of 1988, and that he would energetically seek to prepare the necessary financial and construction details of the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable senator ask his question.
—Would the Minister agree that he has misled the Senate? Would he further agree that Mr Morris, the Minister for Transport, has misled the Australian voter?

—I recall the question being asked. I replied that the policy of the Government at that stage was to give its support for a railway line that would assist the people in the Northern Territory. However, subsequent to my answering that question, the Government has had to review its spending programs, having regard to the impossible financial position in which the previous Government left this country. Consequently, the Government has had to revise a number of its public works programs. It does not resile from its responsibilities in respect of the railway. I am informed by my colleague the Minister for Transport, whom I represent in this place, that the Government suggests that the railway construction should be the joint responsibility of the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory. As this has been the practice for all State railway systems since the colony was established I do not think it is a radical departure from past procedures. A State government may well be interested in the proposal. After all, the railway is an extension of the connecting link between South Australia and the Northern Territory. These matters are currently still being discussed with a view to the project going ahead. Certainly I repudiate any suggestion that I misled the Parliament. What I stated was the Government's commitment at the time the question was asked. The Australian Government hopes to be able to proceed with that commitment. All that has changed is the method of financing the project. This will be a matter for discussion between the relevant State and the Commonwealth.

—Earlier today during Question Time Senator Archer asked me a question about a statement on interest rates made by the Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr Hurford. Since the question was asked I have been advised that the Minister said yesterday in the Bruce electorate that he believed that the economic statement brought down last Thursday outlined such a positive approach to economic management that it would have a downward effect on interest rates. The Minister did not put any time upon a reduction in interest rates. He pointed out that there were many other factors, such as the level of interest rates overseas, which had to be taken into consideration. He said that there was nothing that would help the housing industry more than a downward movement of interest rates but he pointed out to the electors of Bruce, who no doubt are concerned about these matters, that the Government had been left an appalling legacy by its predecessors in the form of a $9.6 billion deficit which the Government inherited on 5 March.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Philippines led by the Honourable Rogelio Sarmiento, Minister of State for Transport and Communications . On behalf of honourable senators I extend to all members of the delegation a warm welcome to the Senate chamber. I express the wish that they enjoy the remainder of their stay in Australia.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a statement in response to the Senate House Committee's inquiry into the organisation, operation, functions and financial administration of the Joint House Department. Honourable senators will recall that the reference to the Committee on 29 October 1981 resulted from the examination by Senate Estimates Committee A of the particulars of proposed expenditure for the year 1981-82. The House Committee subsequently reported to the Senate on 26 August 1982 and, at the time of the double dissolution, my predecessor in the office of President had not been able to respond to the report.

INTERJECT.PARA: On 17 May 1983, the Committee further reported on matters raised following the publication of its initial report. The reports of the Committee generally indicate a number of shortcomings in the past administration of the Joint House Department, and I assure the Senate that I will be paying close attention to measures which, I hope, will rectify that overall situation.
In relation to the specific recommendations of the Committee, Recommendation 1 is that:

. . . each House resolve to empower their respective House Committees, when sitting together as the Joint House Committee, with the executive responsibility for policy in relation to the functions of the Joint House Department--

I inform the Senate that at the meeting of the Joint House Committee on Thursday , 18 May, the Joint House Committee was told that the Speaker and I had agreed that whilst the responsibility for decision making in respect of the Joint House Department must rest ultimately with the Presiding Officers, in making decisions we would be guided by resolutions and determinations of the Committee.
Recommendation 2 is that:
. . . there be a determination of policy by the Joint House Committee covering the nature and level of services to be provided by the Refreshment Rooms-
I agree that the Joint House Committee should consider the matter and make recommendations to the Presiding Officers.
Recommendation 3 is that:
. . . there be a thorough examination as soon as possible of the alternatives for operating all or part of the Refreshment Rooms on a contract or concession basis-
I intend referring this matter to the Joint House Committee for consideration of the method by which the recommendation can be implemented.
Recommendation 4 is that:
. . . immediate consideration be given to contracting out all or part of the cleaning function-

I understand the House Committee was told at its most recent inquiry that some examination of this proposal has now been undertaken by the Joint House Department. Again, I have asked that the proposal be fully evaluated and that the Joint House Department advise the outcome of the evaluation to the Joint House Committee as soon as possible.
Recommendation 5 is that:
. . . the Public Accounts and the Public Works Committee Secretariats be relocated-

This recommendation was implemented by the previous Presiding Officers and the Public Accounts and the Public Works Committee secretariats have been transferred to the Department of the House of Representatives.
Recommendation 6 is that:
. . . the arrangements for night watchmen be immediately revised-

The initial discussions I have had with parliamentary security advisers indicate there is validity in the Committee's conclusion. Discussions are in train between the Speaker and me, and with the relevant parliamentary officers, about existing security arrangements.
Recommendation 7 is that:
. . . the question as to whether Parliamentary staff should have security clearances should be reviewed-
The permanent heads of the parliamentary departments have this recommendation under consideration.
Recommendation 8 is that:
. . . the President and the Speaker look to the Department of the Senate and the Department of the House of Representatives to properly promote the education services of the Parliament-

I accept this recommendation in relation to the Department of the Senate. I have been advised by the Clerk that the promotion of the education services of the Senate is a continuing function, and the enhancement of the service is the subject of constant review.
Recommendation 9 is that:
. . . the Presiding Officers, one or both, give urgent consideration to the tabling of the Urwick Report in the Parliament-

In considering this recommendation, I have also discussed the matter with the Speaker of the House of Representatives and he endorses my decision to table the Urwick report at the conclusion of this statement.
Recommendation 10 is that:

. . . a number of other matters should first be decided before consideration is given to amalgamation of all or part of the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting Staff with the Joint House Department-
I agree with this recommendation and assure the Senate that, bearing in mind my 21 years of parliamentary service, I do not intend proposing such an amalgamation.
Recommendation 11 is that:

. . . the proposal of the Department of Transport and Construction concerning repairs and maintenance be further considered by way of a study aimed at establishing costs, benefits and the effects on Parliament's present technical staff.

I note that the Committee, in making this recommendation, regarded as doubtful any suggestions that the Parliament could be better served by other than its own repairs and maintenance staff. However, like the Committee, I believe there is an obligation to assess whether overall economies can be achieved and I am referring this recommendation to the members of the Joint House Committee for their consideration.

The members of the Committee have put in a lot of time and effort to arrive at the detailed conclusions of their report. The Committee's report has been of great assistance to me and I place on record my appreciation of the valuable work undertaken by the members and the staff of the Senate House Committee. I believe the decisions that have been taken arising from the report will achieve greater efficiencies in the organisation, operation, functions and administration of the Joint House Department. I table the Urwick report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

Mr President, first I say that I think probably the most welcome news that came to us in your statement was that you and the present Speaker have decided to table the Urwick report. The Senate House Committee had access to that report during its deliberations in camera and, as has been indicated, we thought nothing in it should keep it a confidential document. However, for those who are interested and involved in the running of this Parliament House-that is, all members of the Joint House Committee, plus others-a lot of information in that report is very helpful and very useful. Much of it is non-controversial.

It is also welcome that the recommendations of that report, I believe, will now be available to all the staff of this Parliament House so that they can see what recommendations have been made and make their comment and input on decisions that might be taken in relation to the design and function of their jobs in the future. Indeed, in some cases, they might comment on the subject of whether their jobs should even continue to exist. I think it is highly desirable that that information be made available to staff and that they have a detailed knowledge of the things on which they are supposed to be commenting rather than having the system that obtained before whereby the actual recommendations in the report were not available other than to heads of specific departments and very senior personnel.

I note with interest, Mr President, that you intend to refer a number of the recommendations of the Senate House Committee to the Joint House Committee. These recommendations relate to the contracting out of cleaning, the possibility of looking at some sort of concession for the operation of the parliamentary dining rooms and some issues in relation to repairs and maintenance. Mr President, I also note your comment in relation to recommendation 1 which states :

. . . each House resolve to empower their respective House committees, when sitting together as the Joint House Committee, with the executive responsibility for policy in relation to the functions of the Joint House Department . . .

Mr President, I think that in further debate on your statement the Senate as well as the House of Representatives will need to take up this issue and look at , properly, how some authority can be given to that Committee. I can say only that it is a great pity that Senator McLaren is not still with us. If it had not been for the advent of a double dissolution I know which part of your report he would have been speaking on today. For years he advocated some authority being given to the Joint House Committee. I am sure he would be very enthusiastic about any moves in that direction and more notice being taken of the Committee.

Mr President, I have a very particular interest in your response to recommendation 6 in relation to security. I might say-I am sure you have checked the Hansard transcripts-that every witness we questioned on this subject swore black and blue that there was nothing wrong with the arrangement for night watchmen in this place. It was only on the basis of some gossipy type of information members of the Committee had that that recommendation went in. I think possibly it was due to the fact that our recommendation was actually totally contrary to the evidence given to us and that we had reasons to doubt the helpfulness of the evidence that we had a subsequent need for another report from the Senate House Committee.

Mr President, I am interested that you have looked at this matter and believe that there is some validity, as you say, in the Committee's decision. I just emphasise the point that you might find it useful to cast your eyes again over the evidence given in that report because witnesses declared very solidly that our concerns about security, particularly in relation to night watchmen, were not well justified. I realise that I have quite some time available in which to speak but I am intending to proceed on the basis on which we have proceeded with other reports and, that is, basically that a five minute limit applies. Mr President, I am sure that your statement will be noted with interest by all honourable senators and that there will be much more discussion on it, particularly by the Joint House Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to respond briefly to the response that you have brought down to the Senate House Committee report. I fully endorse all that Senator Martin had to say, particularly in relation to security because that has been one of my concerns. One of the other concerns not included in the report is the morale of the members of the staff of Parliament House. This is a matter that I will be referring to, perhaps at a later stage in reference to the Joint House Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate you, Mr President, and Mr Speaker on the decision to table the Urwick report. I remind honourable senators, especially new senators who have recently joined us, that the Urwick report was commissioned by the Presiding Officers and contained a number of what were presumed to be controversial areas. Having obtained the permission of the Senate to view that report, I was pleasantly surprised to find that there was not a great deal of controversy in it. There was an expression of opinion with which I did not necessarily agree, but I did not regard it as being that controversial. I was curious as to why the report could not have been tabled without the Senate House Committee having virtually to beg the Senate for it to be released to it in camera.

I believe that, if reports of this nature are to be brought down, it is the responsibility of all members of the Parliament to have available to them such reports so that we can determine for ourselves whether anything in them will affect the way this place is operated or whether they will affect the way we need this place to operate. Whilst Parliament House belongs to the people, it is the members and senators who are here for such a limited time and who require specific things to be available to them during that time. We must recognise also that the large number of people who work here on a day-by-day basis each week of the year require certain facilities available to them as well.

The situation which has developed certainly over the last couple of years must be put into context. We cannot allow conjecture amongst the staff as to what a particular report says, for the very good reason that it affects and lowers the morale of people if they are not aware of what the report might say and they may be concerned that their positions in Parliament House could be affected by a determination which is made by other people.

I commend the President for bringing down so rapidly a response to the second report of the Senate House Committee. Honourable senators will be aware that I tabled this report only last week. Because it is my intention to look more thoroughly at the statement that you have made today, Mr President, I seek leave to continue my remarks so that the report can remain on the Notice Paper and a contribution can be made by me and other members of the Senate at a later stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a report by the National Women's Advisory Council on special consultations with disabled women and girls. It is a simply written and very direct report which covers the subject of problems that arise for disabled women and girls in the Australian community. The subject matters which are the conclusions of the report were achieved through a particular process in this case. As I understand it, it was a matter of sending out questionnaires to disabled women and girls and then interviewing most of them by telephone. This method took cognisance of their disabilities and difficulty in travelling. A large number of issues are covered, as I have said, very simply and directly and I think very usefully. Many of them are common to all disabled people. There is some emphasis on how a problem that arises as a result of a disability can have a specific effect on a woman.

I wish briefly to draw the notice of the Senate to a few points. One of the early points-a particularly interesting one in relation to debates we have these days on the subject of equality-is the effect that the so-called discrimination in favour of women by giving them the age pension at the age of 60 years instead of the age of 65 years, as in the case of men, has on the disabled. In fact, it is a disadvantage for disabled women. The invalid pension is not taxed but the age pension is. So disabled women who have another source of income, which they need because the cost of living for the disabled is extremely high, lose their invalid pension and are transferred on to the age pension at the age of 60 years , and are then subject to tax. That results in their having less income than a disabled man in otherwise identical circumstances who holds his invalid pension until the age of 65 years.

Another very general issue, which has specific application to disabled women but which I am sure is of more general interest in the community at the moment, is whether the work that a woman does as a mother and in the home is in fact work. This is, of course, a matter of great debate in the community and there are some extremes of views on the subject. It is pointed out in this report that the disabled wife and mother who is carrying out the chores normally carried out by a wife and mother, which at the moment attract no economic reward, needs special assistance particularly in the matter of transport. For example, many disabled mothers must drive a car in order to reach the shops and to carry out their shopping. However, no sales tax concession applies to a car driven in these circumstances. Disabled men or women driving to paid employment would get sales tax concessions on their cars. They would also get some assistance with the extremely high cost of modification of their cars so that they could drive them. Women carrying out this job, which at present does not earn economic reward, get none of those sorts of concessions, although they would believe, and society I think pays lip service to the fact, that they are doing a job which has value.

The report also points out that disabled women carrying out these sorts of household chores and work for the family often have to work with electrical appliances which are designed without any thought of the disabled. Whilst I suppose that this is not an area of government activity, it points out, I hope fairly clearly and forcefully, to those who are in the business of manufacturing electrical appliances that possibly there is a market that they have left untapped in the past. They might look at how they could modify their appliances so that they would have a very particular appeal.

The matter of some disability aids specific to women being unsuitable is also raised. Reference is also made to the very special problems of motherhood for a disabled woman involving not just community attitudes but also doctors' attitudes specifically as to whether a disabled woman should have a baby, even though she may be physically capable of doing so, as well as some additional problems relating to how a disabled woman, for example, the physical strength of whose arms is affected, copes with that situation.
