SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had the great pleasure and privilege on Saturday of attending a meeting of handicapped women and the mothers of handicapped children in Perth at which the report of the National Women's Advisory Council entitled 'So much left undone' was launched by Edith Hall, a member of the Council which organised Saturday's meeting in conjunction with the Young Women's Christian Association. Edith Hall, herself confined to a wheelchair, described very graphically the way in which those women who contributed to this document were asking with great humility for services of simplicity and low expense, the sorts of requests that handicapped people have been making for a very long time. The document before us is the summary only of a much more comprehensive report which goes to two volumes and which I hope will be studied seriously not only by the Government and the Opposition but also by many organisations which have a direct bearing on the way in which the handicapped can function or are prevented from functioning at their optimum. For example, we were told that incontinence pads required by many handicapped people are available only from pharmacies or in bulk, which makes it extremely inconvenient for very many people who need them to obtain the supplies that they obviously must acquire but which, because of financial constraints, they cannot acquire in bulk.
—Is that a legal restriction?

—I am not sure of that. I do not believe it is. I intend to follow the matter further. The report of the International Year of Disabled Persons has still not been published, but I believe it will reflect the types of recommendations made in the report entitled 'So much left undone'. Forty-five per cent of the population suffers from one or more chronic conditions and of that number well over one million are disabled. Of that one million two-thirds are handicapped. Over 50 per cent of identified disabled people are women, the same proportion that women represent in the general population. It is somewhat of a scandal that in Western Australia in the last 12 months only 24 per cent of those receiving rehabilitation are women despite the fact that there are unused facilities within our rehabilitation institutions. There is a considerable lack of awareness in the community of what facilities are available. There is also a lack of awareness of what is required. Reference has already been made by Senator Martin to the fact that sex and sexuality of disabled women is largely unrecognised. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The traditional caring roles also appeared to limit disabled women and girls . . . reducing their opportunities for establishing heterosexual relationships. Disabled men were felt to have a much greater opportunity to relate to women who provided the 'care' for them, whereas disabled women had stepped out of their traditional role in needing rather than providing care.

In addition, when faced with her own inability to fulfil traditional role expectations of a male-female relationship, a disabled woman may consciously or unconsciously avoid personal situations which could lead to deep relationships with the opposite sex. This could be at a severe psychological, emotional, social and sexual cost to her development and fulfilment as a human being.

Time and again the costs of transport are emphasised. One woman told us on Saturday how she had been desperate to work, to gain the experience that a particular job would provide, and found that the only way in which she could carry out that job was to spend something like 90 per cent of her income on taxis. Physical access to buildings recurs as a problem again and again. Many of us have probably been unaware of the fact that the notorious organisation, the Builders Labourers Federation, in the International Year of Disabled Persons placed a black ban on all buildings which did not provide access for the disabled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow Senator Martin and Senator Giles on the report of the National Women's Advisory Council entitled 'So much left undone'. It is a brief report and summary of a much more in-depth document covering these issues. I take interest and real delight in the way this report emphasises that it is the handicapped people themselves who have given the evidence that led to the recommendations contained in it. The report is not planning from on high but is planning by participation. Certainly, I think the recommendations would be fairly easily fulfilled; they are not great and heroic demands. I think that is also a point in this report that is well worth taking more generally. That point was very nicely demonstrated in this report. The report indicates too that the best guesses of the people planning the questionnaire did not actually match the responses of the handicapped women. When the women were asked what their principal problems were their reply was transport. This problem was listed the largest number of times. Access and finance were also mentioned. These points were not listed on the questionnaire but were volunteered by the handicapped women.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, the main emphasis of the requirements of handicapped women was: 'Please, please could we try to live independently?' That request is not put in those terms in the report, but that is the main thrust. Quite some part of the document is devoted to the inadequacies and in fact the considerable humiliations not only of women but of men and women, young and old, living out their lives in hospitals because it is seen that anybody who is disabled is not normal, and anybody who is not normal is clearly sick, and we should put sick people in hospital. Those people say: 'We are not sick; we are disabled. We want to try and live independently'. A number of recommendations stress that point. It is interesting to note that that claim in this report matches very well the claim for support for independent living that is emerging from a large number of groups in our community, in particular the mentally handicapped as well as the physically handicapped.

Often people will claim that it is not cost beneficial to have handicapped people living independently and that it is better to have them institutionalised because of economies of scale. I think those arguments have long since been laid to rest, but I argue that even if it were more expensive to protect people's dignity and to support them in independent living, if that is what those people desire, it ought to be the serious concern of government. There are some things on which we might have to spend our dollars. However this report does not dwell on the cost-benefit analysis.

Another point that was raised by the previous speakers and that I think is very important is the fierce challenge to independent living by handicapped women who find themselves facing the combination of low income and disability that leads them to being very financially constrained. Not only do they find it very difficult to earn a living or even to find support in sheltered workshops where they might get a token sort of income, but to live independently they require appliances, modifications to homes, houses and cars, et cetera, and these are inordinately expensive. As explained by Senator Martin, the sales tax concessions allowable for employed people are not allowable for unemployed people, and that group often includes women. People on a low income have to pay far more to try to manage their independent living. This report is brief and it is simple, but it conveys very powerfully the message of these women: 'Please, could we have some facilities, consideration and understanding in the community to enable us as much as possible to live independently'.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATION OF THE STUDENT ASSISTANCE ACT IN 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report on the operation of the Student Assistance Act in 1982 is an annual reminder of the problems that we face in this country in relation to tertiary education. I refer the Senate to page 14 of this report in particular where, in table 3, we find some very interesting statistics. In 1977, 99,153 students were assisted under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme. For each year thereafter the figures are respectively 98,000, 93,000, 91,000, 91,000, with the preliminary figure for last year being 86,000. I think it is interesting to note that while the number of people in Australia grows, while demands upon tertiary education grow, while the world and particularly the Western countries move into technology, biotechnology and computers-in other words, while the Western countries move into industries which require tertiary education-what do we find in this country? We find that not only is the number of students who are being assisted to undertake tertiary studies dropping every year, but also that the total number of students as a percentage of the population has dropped every year since 1977.

We are saying that we recognise that young people need to move into the work force, that Australia needs a whole variety of new industries to create new jobs and opportunities and that we recognise right the way across the board the valuable input that primary and, in particular, secondary and tertiary education studies make to the economy. Yet we are not willing to support students going into tertiary studies. I think that together those items show the barrenness with which we have approached the education debate in Australia. If we were merely looking at an Act which in some sense could be called non-productive, then indeed, in times of harsh economic climate we may say in regard to finance: 'We would like to, but we cannot'. But we are not talking about an area which is non-productive. We are talking about the area of tertiary education, which we know from overseas experience to be the most directly productive area within the community upon which a government can spend a dollar. This fact has now been recognised, particularly in the studies that have been done on the American economy. Particularly important is the relationship between tertiary studies and those new industries which the new Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Barry Jones, has called sunrise industries. I hope that when we come to the Budget in August we will see for the first time some reversal of this trend which is highlighted on page 14 of the report. Without a reversal of that trend, without at least taking it back to 1977 levels when the Government was assisting 99,000 students instead of, as is the case now, 86,000 students, we will not see any advance.

The other item I wish to point to is the application of the TEAS allowance and the criteria upon which it is made. That is discussed in chapter 3 under the heading: 'General Conditions of Eligibility for TEAS'. I think that again we see there that the major problem that confronts students is not so much that the Government has sought to cut back but that it has sought to make the hurdle more and more difficult. In a sense that runs directly counter to what we know to be the case within the general education community-that unless we are able to assist everybody who needs assistance we are throwing away the valuable talent which is necessary for the development of this country and for future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

SPEECH.PARA: At page 10 of the report, reference is made to the fact that student representation on the student assistance review tribunals is drawn from the Australian Union of Students. It is worth observing that the loans scheme which the previous Government introduced made student loans available to students within the technical and further education sector. The abolition of loans has left those students in the worst of all possible worlds. I ask the Labor Government to consider the special position of disadvantage in which it has placed the students in TAFE by its administrative action. The speech read as follows-

The major purpose of this Bill is to amend the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act 1981 to rectify technical deficiencies which have recently come to light. At the same time, the opportunity is being taken to include in the tax sharing base some newly imposed Commonwealth taxes.

In 1981, an understanding was reached with the States that, following a transitional year, their tax sharing grants would be calculated by reference to a 'total' tax base rather than the personal income tax base used in previous arrangements. That, and other understandings between the premiers and the previous Government, formed the basis of the tax sharing Act. Apart from the provision for certain taxes-or parts thereof-to be declared by the Treasurer to be a special surcharge and thereby be excluded from the tax pool, the Act did appear at the time to cover all major Commonwealth taxation collections. Moreover, to date, determinations of taxation receipts required under the Act have been made in accordance with the understanding with the States. Under section 27 of the Act, a determination once made is presumed conclusively correct.

I record these facts simply for the information of honourable senators present and to assure them that, to date, determinations of tax collections under the Act have been made in accordance with the spirit of the understanding with the States.

Recently, however, questions have arisen as to whether, strictly interpreted, the definition of income tax in the Act is in fact as broad as intended. Advice from Attorney-General's Department has confirmed the doubt that exists regarding this definition.

The definition of income tax in the Act is derived by reference to section 6 (i ) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, a section which deals with assessed income tax only. Collections of PAYE instalments, company tax instalments or provisional tax instalments collected by the Commonwealth are not assessed, within the meaning of the Act, at the time of collection. Late payment penalties would also not strictly be included under the present definition.

It is estimated that around $600m of the net income tax collections in 1981-82 would represent tax not subsequently falling within the definition of the Act. Because of the lag between personal income tax collections and the issue of related assessments, the determination which would have been made in that year, had the strict interpretation of the Act been adopted, would have been substantially below the determination actually made.

Although previous determinations were consistent with the intention of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act, the Government now proposes to make the necessary amendments to bring it into line with those intentions.

As I have already indicated, in addition to amending the definition of income tax included in the tax sharing base, the present Bill also deals with newly introduced Commonwealth taxes. In recent times the Commonwealth has enacted two pieces of legislation, namely, the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act 1982 and the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Act 1982, which should, as part of the understanding reached with the States in 1981, be added to the list of taxes forming the tax base for the purposes of the tax sharing act.

Finally, I note the amendments set out in the Bill also make allowance for the deduction, from the tax sharing base, of any payments which could be made by the Commonwealth under the proposed legislation for the payment of interest on tax overpayments.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill will, among other things, honour an important election commitment to abolish the declaration that pensioners and concessional beneficiaries must sign when they receive pharmaceutical benefits. As honouring this promise involves legislative change, the Government is taking one of the first opportunities in the new Parliament to honour its election pledge.

Honourable senators will recall that the previous Government introduced from 1 January of this year an arrangement under which a pharmaceutical chemist could not supply a benefit item to a pensioner free of charge or to a concessional beneficiary at the reduced contribution rate, unless the patient completed a complex declaration as to this entitlement. The declaration was printed on the reverse of the prescription form thereby requiring two signatures for each prescription, once on the declaration and once for the receipt of the benefit. In practice many patients particularly the aged, the infirm, migrants and the disabled were unable to complete the declaration form without help. There was widespread opposition to the arrangement. Its abolition will be welcomed generally.

I draw honourable senators' attention to clause 6 of the Bill which would establish a far simpler mechanism for pensioners and concessional beneficiaries to claim their entitlement. Under the proposed scheme a pharmacist would be authorised to supply the benefit if the prescription form contains certain basic information about the patient's entitlement. The information needed will be set out in regulations and will be easily available from the benefit cards issued to all persons entitled to free or concessional pharmaceutical benefits. A medical or dental practitioner, the patient or any person on behalf of the patient, or the pharmacist supplying the benefit, will all be allowed to enter the entitlement information on the front of the prescription form.

There will no longer be a need for persons to sign twice in order to obtain supply of the benefit and the patient contribution concession. It is expected that the problems being experienced by patients and pharmacists with the present complex arrangements will disappear.

The new prescription form will simplify the present complex declaration form in four ways. First, all the required information will be provided on one side of the form. There will be no requirements on the reverse side of the form. Second, the information for beneficiary status will be simplified, making it easier for beneficiaries and pharmacists, yet still meeting the necessary demands for effective departmental monitoring. Third, a single signature will indicate both receipt of the prescription and claim to free or concessional entitlement. Fourth, doctors and, if need be, pharmacists, will be encouraged to assist beneficiaries in completing the form. However, I would make it clear that responsibility for the accuracy of an entitlement claim rests, as it rightly should, with the beneficiary.

To discourage fraud, clause 9 of the Bill amends section 103 of the Act, the offence provision, to expressly cover the new procedure and the Department of Health will continue to closely monitor the supply of benefits, and will examine improved monitoring devices to eradicate fraud in the pharmacy area.

Mr President, the opportunity has also been taken in this Bill to amend the National Health Act to ensure effective continuation of established policies and practices in the Commonwealth control of nursing home fees.
I draw honourable senators' attention to clause 3 of the Bill.

The Federal Government's annual contribution to accommodation and home care programs for the aged can be expected to pass the $1000 million mark in the next budget. Of this amount it is estimated that expenditure subsidising the provision of care in nursing homes will account for $865 million. The recurrent funding of nursing home beds considerably overshadows all federal capital expenditure on accommodation for the aged, recurrent funding for hostels and all expenditure on domiciliary care, and it is rising substantially.

While the expenditure on the nursing homes programs continues to escalate significantly there are growing criticisms of the present arrangements. The aged , their families and taxpayers are increasingly questioning the inadequacies, expense and the mismatch of services which comprise Australia's present arrangements for care of the aged. Care of the aged is now an important community and political concern.

The report released last year by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure entitled ''In a home or at home; Accommodation and Home care for the Aged'' is a significant document which identifies the strengths and weaknesses of the present arrangements. The report shows Australia as having a complex, fragmented and expensive system of aged care. A major emphasis of the report is on the preponderance of institutional care over domiciliary and community care and on the need to redress this imbalance. At the same time the report provides clear recommendations aimed at rationalising and improving the present arrangements.

The Government endorses the thrust of this report. As a nation we go on spending very considerable amounts on institutional care of the aged whilst severely restricting funding to those who would prefer to remain at home or in the community.

The Government intends to develop a community care program to provide support for the elderly who wish to remain in their own homes. Under this program there will be a comprehensive range of domiciliary and community services provided across Australia.

On the residential side our task will be to moderate growth in the nursing home sector, while continuing to pursue more equitable geographic distribution of nursing home beds, and to increase the availability of hostel accommodation. It is our view that neither per capita nursing home benefits funding nor deficit funding are ideal methods for securing the proper national development of nursing homes in the context of a total care policy for the aged.

Existing nursing home benefits and deficit funding arrangements will be replaced by program grants paid to nursing homes. These program grants will be based on standard costs for the services delivered less the income received by the homes throught standard patient contributions. The program grant system will take some time to develop. In the meantime the existing funding arrangements for nursing homes, will be maintained.

The principal purpose of clause 3 is to ensure protection for patients against excessive fee increases and at the same time to ensure appropriate control of expenditure on benefits under the current nursing home benefits arrangements pending the introduction of the Government's residential care program. Expenditure on the nursing homes benefits program is determined by the number of approved beds and the level of benefit. The benefit level in each State is related to the levels of nursing home fees in the State which in turn are determined by the Department of Health having regard to costs necessarily incurred by nursing home proprietors.

The existing legislation on the control of fees simply provides that in determining fees the permanent head shall 'have regard to costs necessarily incurred in providing nursing home care in the nursing home.' Two recent federal court judgments have shown that this legislation is not able to support the policies and practices followed over many years in the administration of fees control-policies and practices which have been followed by both labor and liberal/national party governments. These judgments have serious implications for the overall cost of the nursing homes benefits program.

The practical effect of the judgments is that the continued application of the policies and practices currently used in the determination of fees for nursing homes would result in many determinations being set aside, if challenged, as being made contrary to law. Costs which previously were not allowed for the purpose of setting fees now have to be given consideration possibly resulting in significant fee increases contrary to Government policy. This would lead to higher benefits and therefore increased Government expenditure.

Within the protected environment of the nursing home industry, there is very little incentive to constrain costs given the cost-based nature of fees determination and the high occupancy rates resulting from Government controls on new beds. Limited costs validations undertaken by the Department of Health have revealed cases where costs have been artifically increased as a means of increasing profits. A recent consultancy survey undertaken with the co-operation of the industry revealed considerable variations in costs and profits between like homes.

Legal opinion has been given to the effect that, in the light of the Federal Court judgments, the legislation greatly circumscribes the use of policy guidelines. Consequently, very great burdens will be placed upon delegates of the permanent head whose task it is to determine fees. The judgments interpret the legislation as requiring the permanent head and his delegates to regard all costs necessarily incurred as fundamental matters for consideration, with each fee being determined on the basis of the merits of each individual case. The considerable difficulties involved in maintaining consistent administration Australia-wide will be exacerbated. Successive governments have acted on the basis that parliament, in passing the fees control legislation, did not intend to limit significantly central control and accountability, particularly given that the legislation makes detailed provision for appeals against, and reviews of, delegates determinations.

There are indications that the effect of the Federal Court judgments could be an eventual increase in Government expenditure on benefits of the possible order of $50 million per annum. In a program which is expected to cost more than $600 million for benefits alone in 1983-84, it is imperative that consistent and effective controls be exercised on costs which may have an inflationary effect on approved fees.

The effect of clause 3 will be to allow the effective continuation of established policies and practices pending the introduction of the Government's residential care program. The Bill provides that the Minister for Health may formulate principles in accordance with which the permanent head or his delegate is required to determine a scale of fees. It is intended that the principles will reflect established policy. The Bill provides for scrutiny of the principles by Parliament. In formulating these principles, regard is to be had to the factors set down in the proposed sub-section 40AA (7B). These factors will permit delegates to take account of the lack of normal market constraints on the nursing home industry.

Clause 4 of the Bill is designed to ensure that the Minister is not, of necessity, constrained by principles authorised by clause 3 which are intended to limit the discretion of a large number of delegates of the permanent head throughout the country. Thus, on appeal, the Minister may, in considering the merits of a case, decide that rigid application of the principle is inappropriate. This change puts beyond legal doubt a practice which has been followed by successive ministers of governments of all complexions.

In summary, the proposed changes will ensure that the Government is able to continue the application of policies and practices in nursing homes fees control , established and supported by successive governments, pending the introduction of the present government's residential care program.

I now turn to clause 5 of the Bill which relates to the domiciliary nursing care benefit. Honourable senators will be aware that this benefit is paid to persons who care for persons, generally relatives, in their own homes rather than having them admitted to nursing homes. To attract this benefit, persons are medically assessed by their own doctor and by a Commonwealth medical officer as requiring continuing nursing care to an extent that admission requirements to a nursing home would be satisfied.

Other eligibility criteria for the benefit include that the person providing care and the patient must be domiciled in the same residence and regular nursing attention must be provided by a registered nurse.

Where a person ceases to provide domiciliary nursing care to a patient, section 58J of the National Health Act provides that the permanent head of the Department of Health or his delegate shall revoke approval of the benefit.

At present, this provision restricts the delegation of the power of revocation to a departmental medical practitioner. This restriction results in unnecessary diversion of medical staff resources in that revocation of an approval often results from non-medical considerations such as a change in residential arrangement or, indeed, the death of a patient.

It is this unnecessary restriction in section 58J which is removed by the amendment in clause 5. Of course, a delegate would have available, if required in the process of exercising the delegation to revoke an approval, the advice of medical practitioners and other professional personnel.

The amendment does not remove the inherent requirement in the domiciliary nursing care arrangements that a decision, requiring medical judgment, which may result in the revocation of an approval for the benefit, can only be made by a medical practitioner. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is one of a package of Bills, the main purpose of which is to introduce a new system for granting tariff concessions. The new system, to be known as the Commercial Tariff Concession System, is a modification of and replaces the existing Commercial By-law System.

By-laws have been an integral part of the customs tariff since federation. Presently, under Part XVI of the Customs Act and particularly section 273, a concessional rate of duty can be applied to imported goods which comply with criteria prescribed in a by-law tariff item. In other words, the existing by-law system provides the legal means of removing duties (other than duties of a revenue nature) which serve no protective purpose.

The sole and long-standing criterion for concessional by-law entry is where suitably equivalent goods are not reasonably available from local production. Considerable difficulty has emerged with this criterion on economic, administrative and legal grounds and as a result the commercial by-law system was referred to the Industries Assistance Commission in April 1981 for review. This was the first complete review of the by-law system.

The Industries Assistance Commission reported to the Government of the Day on 2 July 1982 and the new Commercial Tariff Concession System encompassed in this legislation is largely based on the Commission's recommendations.

The Commission found that the Commercial By-law System provides flexibility in tariff administration and has widespread support in the business community. Many production activities depend to some extent on the by-law entry of inputs and there could be serious disruption if the by-law system was terminated quickly without a prior comprehensive review of all assistance provided by the Tariff.

While one Commissioner recommended ultimate abandonment of the by-law system, the majority concluded that the present system should be maintained in an improved form. The Government has accepted this majority view.

In broad terms the Government has adopted a new criterion which will provide that commercial tariff concessions will be issued where the Minister is satisfied that no goods serving similar functions are produced or are capable of being produced in the normal course of business in Australia.

The key words in the criterion are 'serving similar functions' and new section 269B (4) provides an interpretation of them. The test will be the degree of cross-elasticity of demand between the imported and Australian produced goods. In practical terms, this means that these tariff concessions will be decided by determining the effect that a reduced rate of duty will have on competition or potential competition between the local and imported goods. This will be based on a practical and realistic assessment of the market situation. The onus will be on the applicant for a tariff concession to identify the goods involved, the market for the goods and the degree of competition or potential competition between the imported goods and Australian-made goods.

Notwithstanding this criterion being met, the proposed new section 269E provides that the Minister may refuse to grant a concession if he considers that such a concession would have a substantially adverse effect on the market available to goods produced in Australia or if it would not be in the national interest.

The Bill also provides in section 269D that concessional entry will not apply in respect of certain classes or kinds of goods. The classes or kinds of goods envisaged are those where there exists a wide and comprehensive range of both Australian-made and imported goods which, notwithstanding differences in construction, quality, price, etc., basically compete with each other in the market place. Included in this category are foodstuffs, motor vehicles, footwear and jewellery. These exclusions will be prescribed in an 'exclusions schedule' in the customs regulations.

Comparing the new criterion with the existing one, the proposed new criterion conforms more closely with established industry assistance objectives and should reduce disagreement and legal disputation over fine technical points in respect of particular goods. It should result in a more predictable administration for users of the system. The new criterion reflects to a large extent the way in which the current by-law system has in fact been administered in recent years using the Minister's discretionary power under the existing legislation.

Other aspects of the system proposed in this legislation include the requirement for advertising applications for new concessions in the Commonwealth Gazette. This will make for better public scrutiny of the system, particularly by local manufacturers whose views will be taken into account prior to a decision being made on an application.

The effective date of new concessions is proposed to be a date no earlier than the date of receipt by the Department of Industry and Commerce of the application or a notice of intention to lodge an application.
In the case of revocation of an existing concession, the Bill provides that concessional entry will be accorded to goods that are in transit to Australia at the date of revocation.
There are two other aspects on which I would like to comment. The first relates to end-use security and shortfall concessions and the other relates to the review of existing by-law concessions.

The new system does not provide for concessions involving end-use under security provisions or situations involving shortfalls in supply. This is the only area of potential significant loss of concessional entry following the adoption of the new criterion.
The reasons for the exclusion of these special concessions are contained in the Industries Assistance Commission report.
In respect of concessions for particular end-uses, the Commission found that these have created a number of problems in principle, in their economic effect and in administration.

To illustrate these problems, if it is necessary to restrict the availability of a concession to a particular use, there must be locally produced goods available. End-use concessions also lead to different rates of duty being paid on the same product by different importers depending on the use to which it is put. Demand can be influenced as a result. The validity of entry under such a concession must depend on there being safeguards to ensure that the imports are only used in the specified end-use. It is a fact of life that this has created considerable administrative difficulties as these conditions are often costly and nigh on impossible to control. This also raises the question of the potential for erosion of the protection already accorded to local industry.

Existing end-use by-laws will be phased out over the next two years and any future proposals for arrangements of this kind will be considered for reference to the Industries Assistance Commission as special by-laws outside the tariff concession system.

In respect of concessions to cover shortfalls, that is, where local industry is unable to maintain normal output, the Commission did not see these concessions as appropriate within the new concession system. Existing arrangements will, however, remain until they are reviewed by the Commission. Future applications for such shortfall concessions, and any cases involving extraordinary demands, will be considered for reference to the Commission. Any resulting concession of this kind will likewise be introduced as a by-law outside the new system.
This leads me to the second matter, the review of existing by-laws and the granting of tariff concessions.

I have already mentioned the position in relation to end-use and shortfall by- laws. Other existing commercial by-laws will be reviewed and new concessions issued where the new criterion is satisfied. This will be done gradually over a two-year period to accord importing and manufacturing interests a reasonable time in which to consider the implications of any changes for their business and minimize any disruption likely to occur.

Decision taken under the new tariff concession system will be reviewable by the existing internal review system within the department of industry and commerce. The legislation makes provision for applicants who wish to make further requests for review to seek a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission. Also, operation of the new system will be subject to review under the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.
Subject to the passage of this legislation through the Parliament, an extensive programme is proposed to fully acquaint importing and manufacturing interests with the new system.
Consequential amendments have been made to the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Act 1975.
The Bill also includes two other matters which are quite separate from the tariff concession provisions.

Clause 3 of the Bill provides that Papua New Guinea content is to be included in determining whether goods are to be regarded as the manufacture of a forum island country, a declared preference country or a developing country. This amendment is in accordance with an agreement reached with the Government of Papua New Guinea.
Clause 4 removes the requirements that goods eligible for tender quota must be imported and entered for home consumption within the same quota period.

The intention of the existing legislation was to prevent goods being held back from entry to take advantage of a lower rate of duty which might apply in a later quota period. Experience shows that this fear has little basis.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT (ELECTION BLACKOUT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Governor-General, in his Speech to the Parliament on 21 April 1983, stated that the Broadcasting and Television Act would be amended to 'remove the ban on political news and comment applying to radio and television stations in the three days before Federal and State elections'. I am pleased to introduce this Bill, which amends the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, and honours the Government's commitment to remove the election 'blackout'. The only election matter which remains subject to restrictions is paid advertisements. The Bill also seeks to reduce the administrative burden on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

We are well aware of the controversy which is caused by the 'blackout' each time an election is held. The momentum that has built up over the years for removal of this provision could not and should not be ignored, because the ' blackout' is simply not supported by most Australians. Amongst members of Parliament it is rejected not only by members on this side of the Senate, but by a number of members opposite. It is opposed by the broadcasting industry; it is opposed by the print media, and it is opposed by most public interest groups associated with the media. Not to put too fine a point on it, the present provisions are an infringement of our civil liberties which should not be tolerated by a democratic society. In fact, the Human Rights Commission, prior to the last election, had already initiated an inquiry into section 116 of the Broadcasting and Television Act, the section which contains the 'blackout' provisions, on the grounds that it violated internationally accepted political rights.

The Government believes that Australians are entitled to receive news and comment on the issues of the day at all times. They are certainly entitled to such news and comment in the process of an election when they are exercising their democratic right to choose a Government. Even if it were possible to justify this abrogation of free speech-of the rights of free men and women to decide for themselves-there would be no logic in denying such information to the public via the electronic media, while simultaneously allowing the print media to report it in full. Radio and television broadcasters, who have been asking successive Governments to lift the 'blackout' year after year, are entitled to describe this as discrimination. The Government accepts their argument and has moved to end this discrimination.

The Bill provides that the 'blackout', from midnight of the Wednesday immediately preceding the election to the close of polls on the following Saturday, will apply in future to paid election advertisements only. All other election matter, including news, current affairs and political commentary, is a legitimate part of the public debate and should not be suppressed.

Of course all parties would oppose a broadcaster favouring one party over another, either in its news and current affairs or in its provision of free time . The right to broadcast carries with it a corresponding responsibility to act with impartiality in matters of public interest. The coverage of elections- indeed of all political matter-should be handled by broadcasters in the most sensitive manner, so that neither listeners and viewers, nor we politicians, are prompted to cry ''foul'' and seek to impose restrictions on all because of the sins of the few. The Bill therefore seeks to extend the existing obligation for broadcasters to afford reasonable opportunity for the broadcasting or televising of election matter to all political parties contesting the election which were represented in the last preceding Parliament, so that it covers the whole election period. That is, in future this responsibility will exist from the issue of writs to the close of polls.
The Government also intends to examine the general question of fairness in the presentation of public issues by the electronic media.
The Minister for Communications is currently considering draft terms of reference for an inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which will allow a full and free public debate on this issue.

The Broadcasting and Television Act currently requires the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to notify any broadcaster who is exempted from the '' blackout'' on broadcasting election matter. When a Federal by-election is held, the Tribunal therefore is required to notify the majority of radio and television stations, that is, those not received in the electorate concerned. The ''blackout'' now will only apply to election advertisements, but it also seeks to assist the Tribunal by substituting a duty to advise only those stations who are subject to restrictions. In the example just mentioned, the Tribunal would need to notify only a few stations. The stations notified, of course, are required to comply with the notice.

It should be noted that since they are prohibited from playing any advertisements, the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Special Broadcasting Service will no longer be subject to any election ''blackout''.

The Bill defines ''election advertisements'' as advertisements which contain election matter and for which payment, whether by money or other consideration, is made directly of indirectly to the licensee of the radio or television station concerned. That is to say, advertisements broadcast on commercial stations and sponsorships broadcast on public broadcasting stations will not be able to contain election matter in the three days before the poll.

The Bill before the Senate is slight in form but highly significant, because it introduces a reform which has been delayed for too long. There is a need for other laws reforming the way elections are conducted in Australia, but this reform is unarguably justified. The Government believes that Australia is a democratic society with a mature electorate and responsible broadcasters providing that electorate with the information it needs to make balanced judgments on public issues. The electorate's need for accurate and informed comment is never more urgent than in the process leading up to the choice of Governments. It is high time that we in the Parliament recognised this and repudiated the paternalism embodied in the present legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill implements two important aspects of the Government's industrial relations policy which was so soundly endorsed by Australians at the last election. Our policy in this area is designed to improve industrial relations in this country, something which is essential if the process of Australia's economic recovery is not to be impeded. The proposals before honourable senators will contribute to the achievement of that objective.

I draw the attention of Honourable Senators to the background of the first area of Government policy dealt with in the Bill, namely, the abolition of the Industrial Relations Bureau and the re-establishment of the Arbitration Inspectorate.
The Bureau was established by the Fraser Government in 1977. It was ill- conceived and it was not wanted by employers or the union movement. From the outset, both groups have sought its abolition.

The Bureau was presented by the Fraser Government as the 'third-arm' of the conciliation and arbitration machinery, to complement the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Federal Court. It was described as being an independent body with the role of securing the observance of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, the Regulations and Awards. It took over the labour inspection role of the Aribration Inspectorate, and was also given responsibility for enforcing a battery of new provisions which intruded the Bureau into the internal affairs of registered organizations and applied new sanctions to employers and unions.

The Fraser Government believed that industrial relations could be controlled by legislative prescription, without proper consideration of the reality of industrial relations in Australia. The Industrial Relations Bureau was perceived as the machinery for implementing the Government's approach to industrial relations.

Such an approach has never worked and will never do so. It is not an approach that will be taken by the Labour Government which is committed to working with the union movement and employers and their associations to achieve better industrial relations in the interests of all Australians.

Moreover the Government believes, and both the union movement and employers agree, that labour inspection will be more appropriately carried out if it is vested once again in an adequately resourced Arbitration Inspectorate which is ultimately responsible to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and within his Department.

This is how the Inspectorate operated before the regrettable creation of the Bureau. The Bill restores this position, reflecting what was in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act before provision was made for the Bureau. There are some minor alterations to enhance the administration of the Inspectorate.

I should stress, Mr President, that the proposed legislation will not give the Inspectorate the intrusive role that the Bureau had in respect of the internal affairs of registered organizations. It will, as it did previously, be required to secure the observance of the Act, the Regulations and of awards. Its principal function will be to ensure that awards of the Commission are being observed. I point out to honourable senators that, again as was the case previously, the powers and duties of inspectors will be as determined by the Minister. They will be open to public scrutiny by publication in the Gazette.

I turn now to the second policy area covered by the Bill. This concerns the facilitation of amalgamations under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act of registered organizations of employers and employees.

It is widely recognised that there are too many unions in Australia. This has produced many problems in Australian industrial relations. For example, there are difficulties in dispute resolution where many unions are often involved; demarcation disputes present their own particular problems.

The National Labour Consultative Council considered this problem over a number of years and in 1980 put forward proposals to encourage amalgamations of registered organisations. These recommendations were designed to facilitate amalgamations in the public interest where registered organizations could establish a community of interest between their industrial interests. Criteria were agreed upon for such a community of interest to be established before a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and, in such a case, the minimum voting requirements under the Act for amalgamation ballots were to be reduced.

These proposals were accepted by the Fraser Government and indeed endorsed by the then Prime Minister in his election policy in 1980. However the then Government abandoned them in favour of unworkable proposals for industry unions which the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation last year concluded would increase industrial disputation.

Mr President, the Bill proposes the introduction of the 1980 NLCC recommendations, with some alterations which have been developed in a review of those recommendations by the Government in consultation with the NLCC to make them more effective. The NLCC has agreed that its earlier proposed community of interest criteria be widened to encourage desirable amalgamations, such as between the unions in the textile, clothing and footwear industries whose attempts to amalgamate have been frustrated by the existing provisions and may have continued to be frustrated if the community of interest provisions had not been widened beyond those originally proposed by the NLCC.

The Bill will also facilitate amalgamations which involve more than two organizations, whether such amalgamations are under the existing provisions, which continue to operate, or under the proposed community of interest provisions. Honourable senators will note that all amalgamations will also benefit from a further provision of the Bill to bring voting rolls in amalgamation ballots more up to date. These provisions also reflect the NLCC recommendations.
It is important to note, Mr President, that there has been full consultation with the NLCC on all the provisions of the Bill and they are agreed with by the Council.
I now wish to outline these provisions in greater detail for honourable senators.

In relation to the abolition of the Bureau, the Bill repeals Part VIA of the Act which provides for the establishment and general powers of the Bureau and removes its specific rights and responsibilities.

For the purposes of securing the observance of the Act, the Regulations and awards, the Bill provides for the appointment of inspectors within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations broadly along the same lines as applied to the former Inspectorate.

As I have said, certain changes will be made to the former arrangements to enhance the administration of the Inspectorate. In particular, appointments to the position of inspector are only to be under the Public Service Act and the power of the Minister to appoint inspectors to carry out their functions under the Act will be capable of delegation to a senior officer of the Department.

Inspectors will again be given powers to enter buildings, interview persons and inspect documents for the purpose of ascertaining whether awards and the requirements of the Act and Regulations are being observed. However, the former power to require the production of documents is to be made more effective to allow inspectors to require employers by notice in writing to produce documents at the premises of the inspector. This power would only be exercisable where there was a failure by the employer to produce that material at his or her agent 's premises at all or within a reasonable time.
Where breaches of federal awards are detected, inspectors will be able, if it is necessary to do so, to bring proceedings before a court for a penalty under the Act.
I again emphasize, Mr President, that as previously the powers and duties of inspectors will be as laid down by the Minister.
As was previously the case the Bill will allow for arrangements to be made for State and Federal labour inspectors to operate within the respective jurisdictions on a reciprocal basis.

There are some provisions of the Act in respect of which the Government believes that the role of the Bureau would more properly be exercised by the Industrial Registrar. Accordingly, upon the abolition of the Bureau, its responsibilities for investigations of deficiencies in the accounts and financial statements of registered organisations will be taken over by the Industrial Registrar. He will also take the place of the Bureau as one of the parties able to apply to the Federal Court for a declaration as to whether a person is eligible to be appointed or elected to an office in an organization or to continue to hold such an office. The Industrial Registrar will also assume the sole responsibility for the conduct of investigations into irregularities alleged in applications for inquiries into elections in organizations, a role which he had prior to the creation of the Bureau.
The Bill also contains transitional provisions to enable proceedings under the Act in a Court at the time of the abolition of the Bureau to be proceeded with at the discretion of the Minister.
Mr President, I turn now to provisions of the Bill dealing with the amalgamation of registered organizations.

Honourable Senators will be aware that the existing legislation requires that, for an amalgamation to be successful, each organization must achieve a return of ballot papers in the amalgamation ballot from at least fifty per cent of members eligible to vote, and of those voting formally, more than half must vote in favour of the amalgamation.
The Bill provides for an easing of these requirements in relation to organizations which can establish a community of interest in respect of their industrial interest.

Organizations which apply to the Industrial Registrar to amalgamate will be able, at the same time, to apply to a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a declaration that the proposed amalgamation is in the public interest and in the industrial interests of those organizations. The Commission is to be empowered to make that declaration where it is satisfied that the amalgamation would further the objects of the Act and that there is a community of interest between the organizations in respect of their industrial interests.

The Bill sets out a number of criteria under which the Commission can determine whether a community of interest exists. Organizations will be required to meet only one of those criteria. For employee organizations those criteria are that a substantial number of the members of each of the organizations are either:
eligible to become members of the other organization or each of the other organizations;
engaged in the same work, aspects of the same work or in similar work;
bound by the same awards;
employed in the same or related work by employers engaged in the same industry; or
engaged in work, or in industries, in respect of which there is a community of interest.
Similar criteria will apply to employer organizations.

Where organizations obtain a declaration from the Commission, they will be required in an amalgamation ballot to achieve a return of ballot papers from only twenty five per cent of members eligible to vote and a simple majority of valid votes would be sufficient to approve the amalgamation.
The Bill contains two other initiatives which will apply to amalgamations whether under the existing amalgamation provisions or the provisions for community of interest amalgamations.

First, in an amalgamation involving more than two organizations, provision is made for the applicants to provide for alternative schemes of amalgamation. If in a ballot one or more of the organizations fails to secure the necessary support for the amalgamation, the amalgamation may still proceed in respect of those organizations the members of which voted in favour of an alternative scheme of amalgamations. Under the existing legislation those organizations would be forced to repeat the entire amalgamation process.

The second initiative relates to the persons who are eligible to participate in an amalgamation ballot. Significant difficulties are faced by organizations in achieving a successful amalgamation because of the existing requirements in this area. Under the Act at present, the roll of voters consists of persons who were financial members of the organization at any time within the 12 months before the day on which the Registrar gave his approval for the amalgamation to be submitted to ballot. Moreover the ballot may not be conducted for several months after that date. Consequently the roll may not accurately reflect the actual membership of the organizations.

In order to overcome this problem, the Bill provides that the roll of voters will comprise those persons who, one month before the opening date of the ballot , were eligible under the rules of the organization to vote in an amalgamation ballot, or where the rules do not so provide, persons who were eligible under the rules to vote in a rank and file election for an office within the organization.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill, originally introduced to this Parliament by former Senator John Siddons, is designed to encourage the introduction of industrial democracy in Australian enterprises.
The Australian Democrats believe the participation of employees in making decisions which affect their work place is a basic democratic right and as important as the right to vote.

This is a fundamental freedom which can be won only by careful thought and attention to detail. I refer to the humanisation of the work place, to an organisational structure that frees people to use their qualities of imagination , initiative, technical expertise, sociability and leadership during the eight- hour working day. Nothing, certainly not money, can compensate for eight hours of monotonous, mind-killing work. If people are not free to use their human qualities during the eight-hour work day, continued industrial strife is inevitable. The humanisation of the work-place is one of the greatest challenges facing Australia and the Western world today, and likely to face it for the rest of this century.

Unfortunately, there are no hard and fast rules on how this can be achieved, but there are principles which, if adopted, lead us in the right direction. This Bill is designed to encourage companies to adopt these principles and work out how they can be specifically applied in their organisations. The principles are: A cellular organisational structure, profit sharing, employee share ownership and consultative councils.

The Bill calls for the setting up of a seven-member industrial democracy board which would have three members nominated by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, three nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and one nominated by the President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, all for terms of three years. The Board would be supported by a small secretariat. The Board would create and maintain a register of individual democracy enterprises, which would be available for public inspection. The register would list each enterprise which, in the opinion of the board, substantially complied with the criteria laid out in the Bill.

These criteria are: That at least 14 per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise is owned by employees or held by employees under contract of sale through an employee share purchase trust; that the activities of the enterprise are carried out through autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise; that a profit sharing scheme has been established in the enterprise; and that a consultative council has been established. We believe these criteria are achievable, but we recognise that in virtually all enterprises considerable reorganisation would be required. In this legislation's first year of operation it is thus likely that only a small number of enterprises would be able to satisfy the criteria, but over a period of years more and more would see the value of this enlightened approach.

I would like now to examine the criteria in some detail and to discuss briefly the reasons why they have been advanced. Fourteen per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise, or about one-seventh, seems to us to be a reasonable proportion which most companies and their employees could afford. For example, a company which had 1,000 employees and 20 million 50c shares would be required to sell 2.8 million shares to its employees, which means they would receive 2,800 each. If these were bought over five years, it would cost the employees $280 a year or $5.39 a week. However, under the procedure we have outlined, they would receive a dividend on the shares in full, so they would not be out of pocket to any great extent.

Alternatively, the shares could be bought over a period of 10 years, in which case the company would have to declare only a 12.5 per cent dividend, allowing for average income tax of 20 per cent, for employees to enjoy a rate of return equal to their cash outlay in the first year. Once the shares were fully paid for, the employee shareholders would continue to profit as would any shareholder . Employee share ownership achieves an important synthesis between labour and capital. For too long Australia has been bedevilled by a confrontationist approach to industrial relations. Industrial democracy is an important step on the road to industrial relations sense, of which this country desperately needs a large dose.

Employee share ownership is not enough by itself. We believe worker involvement should and could go further, to the shop floor and throughout the enterprise. Overseas and Australian experience has shown the enormous value of autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise. One need cite only the example of Japan to be aware of the advantages of such an approach. Experience has shown that these groups are most effective when they have between 10 and 50 members.

The Bill also provides for a consultative council to have half of its members elected by secret ballot of employees and half nominated by the management of the enterprise, with an alternating chairman. The council will have the function of discussing, and making recommendations to the management in respect of such things as working conditions, safety, long term planning, budgeting and internal decision-making processes. The council-I stress this-will not discuss, or make recommendation in respect of, matters directly concerning awards or rates of pay , or other matters which should be considered by trade unions.

The board would have the power to refuse registration, or to deregister enterprises which did not provide such information as the board considered necessary to inform its judgments with reasonable notice. The key point of the Bill is that tax payable by companies which satisfied the criteria of the board would be reduced by 8 per cent. Before honourable senators jump to conclusions about the cost of such a proposal, let me explain that we believe the cost to the Commonwealth would be nothing like $400m, which is what the cost would be if every company immediately met the criteria.

Many companies, particularly multinationals, would not be willing to issue 14 per cent of their share capital to employees, or to Australians at all. The reaction of Shell to a suggestion that it sell to Australians 25 per cent of its equity in Australia presumably is typical. Our own estimate is that in the first year not more than 5 per cent of companies would meet the criteria at a cost of no more than $20m. Fortunately, however, these companies would tend to be labour -intensive companies and would therefore benefit most from the introduction of these principles. The Government would not necessarily lose out in the long run. Experience has shown the introduction of industrial democracy greatly increases efficiency and productivity-that is a most important point-and it is thus quite probable that profits, hence tax, will rise also.

The Bill which I have presented today is simple and logical. If enacted, it would bring Australia to the forefront of those countries that have adopted an enlightened approach to industrial relations, for example, the Scandinavian countries, Germany and Japan. I commend the Bill.

In other words, that involves anything to do with honey from the time it is produced-and prior to its production but associated with its production presumably-right through to the power formerly provided, that is, the power in relation to the export of honey and to its sale and distribution after export. This proposal will increase dramatically the powers of the Australian Honey Board by giving it virtually total power provided by regulations which may or may not be able to be appropriately dealt with by the Parliament within a reasonable period. One can have a situation in which regulations are made in November or December and the Parliament has no hope of disallowing them, if it is so minded, for some four months after that. This proposal would enable the whole of this industry to be operated by regulation. It would enable the Australian Honey Board to have powers which are far wider and greater than those it has been given by statute to date.
A further provision is to amend section 23A by deleting that part of it which refers to making advances to the owners of honey. Section 23A (a) reads:
With the concurrence of the Treasurer, the Minister may-
(a) arrange with the Reserve Bank of Australia for the making by the bank of loans to the Board for the purpose of enabling the Board to acquire honey or . . .
The Bill seeks to amend that by substituting these words:
to make advances to the owners of honey or to perform any functions prescribed by the regulations for the purposes of paragraph 16 (f).

The Bill seeks to bring in incredibly wide powers, such as those proposed in the amendment to section 16 (f) of the Honey Industry Act, which powers can be created and granted to the Australian Honey Board by regulation. I submit that that is not a matter which is appropriate or proper to be dealt with by a Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill. It ought to be considered in a specific Bill introduced for the purpose of amending separately the Honey Industry Act, which Bill the Senate may at that stage consider it appropriate to refer back to the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to ensure that the alterations being made are in accordance with the recommendations that that Committee has previously made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly in support of the amendment moved by Senator Peter Rae. I refer the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to what he stated in his second reading speech which sets out a particular circumstance and which states that the basis for wanting this extra regulatory power is to provide a function for the Australian Honey Board which it is intended the Board should have. The Honey Industry Act, as it stands at the moment, includes a section which specifically sets out and enumerates the functions of the Board. The Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill intends that an extra extension be included in that Act to give power by regulation to extend the Board's function. If there is a specific function in mind, then I would submit that it would have been a better alternative to have stated that in the functions in the Act. Another amendment to the Act may be needed to complete it, but that would have been a better way of dealing with the matter rather than introducing a miscellaneous provisions Bill to extend the power to give additional function by regulation; in other words, as Senator Peter Rae stated, to extend that power without limit. I am sure that no attempt is being made here to introduce a matter of a controversial nature by means of this extension of power because the Attorney-General has given the specific example in his second reading speech. In supporting the amendment moved by Senator Peter Rae I respectfully suggest to the Attorney-General that in reconsidering this matter he might look to providing specifically in the Act the additional function that he detailed in his second reading speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the force of the arguments that have been put by both Senator Peter Rae and Senator Hill and would appreciate a further response by them to what I am now about to put to them. It is clear, as was indicated in the supplement to my second reading speech that was tabled in the Parliament, that the sole objective that the Government has in mind in seeking to extend the functions or the range of functions of the Australian Honey Board is to enable the Board to make advances to owners of honey on satisfactory forms of security other than security on honey itself. At present advances can be made only on the security of honey, but it has been found, and indeed established that that is really a pretty ineffective form of security. In the event of a producer going broke, the Board would be an unsecured creditor, which raises all sorts of obvious difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: Further, the policy consideration that is motivating the desire to have an extended function in this respect is that the Board has made loans over the years, which have been to the advantage of producers. If this amendment were pulled out with the resulting inability of the Board to act so as to get the security it desires, then the Department of Primary Industry might have to recommend the cessation of such loans altogether, with consequential difficulties to producers. I state clearly that that is the context in which this amendment is brought forward. However, I accept that the language of the amendment is much wider than is strictly necessary to accomplish that relatively limited aim and that there are all sorts of other functions that could now be vested in the Board by regulation. As to that, I simply say further that section 32 of the Honey Industry Act provides, as is common in these matters, that the Governor-General-in-Council cannot make regulations which are in any way inconsistent with the Act. So that hurdle would have to be overcome as would, of course, the option for disallowance which is always retained by this chamber in respect of regulations which engage in overreach. I make the further point, although I appreciate that it is not necessarily calculated to win Senator Peter Rae's heart, that a provision in similar terms appears in the Dairying Industry Act 1924. General functions powers of this kind are, I am advised, not uncommon in primary industry legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably all too common.

—As a former acolyte of Senator Peter Rae on the Senate Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I make it clear that I understand and accept the force of what he is saying. It really reduces to this: Is the Opposition prepared to accept what I am saying-that this will be the sole purpose for which the additional powers will be exercised in order to establish security? Or will it not take that particular proposition on trust and insist in effect on delaying the capacity of the Board, with all the consequential disadvantages that may flow to producers and the Board itself, by insisting on removing this provision from the Bill? I really throw the onus, as it were, back to the Opposition benches to see, in the light of the explanation that I have given to this clause, just how serious it is about pursuing this matter. Perhaps the Australian Democrats, who hold the balance in these matters as in so many others, will give an appropriate indication at this point as to what their attitude is in the light of the explanation and the statement of intention that I have just made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the reason. I referred to the reason. SPEECH.PARA: I could not understand why a honey producer, already suffering a downturn in an industry which has had poor prices, who has already possibly had to mortgage his property, has to go out of business because he cannot get an advance, although he has honey available as security. The Attorney-General raised the question of the regulations not being inconsistent with the Honey Industry Act. The Bill states 'such other functions in connexion with honey'. It could not be any wider. It provides the widest conceivable regulation-making power. I do not think that anything remotely to do with honey could be regarded as being outside the regulation-making power. Bearing in mind that we are in the Committee stage of the debate, I invite an answer before continuing.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the Democrats going to do?

They seem to me to be one inside the other. I do not know that the amendment does anything except give someone enormous powers.

—For the edification of Senator Lewis, I will pass on to him the information that I have already passed on to the Attorney-General and to Senator Peter Rae; that is, that the Australian Democrats are minded to support Senator Rae's amendment. However, I point out as a matter of public relations that when one wants support from people it is a good idea not to be rude to them in advance.

—It would appear that, in the immortal concepts of the late Senator Kennelly, the Government confronts a situation in which it has neither the logic nor the numbers on this matter. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). In those circumstances, I also indicate that the Opposition would wish to co-operate in the course of action which he proposed. I thank the Attorney-General for the action.

—Senator Haines's remarks were only barely relevant, if that, to the Bill. If Senator Gareth Evans likes to give an answer to the question, he may do so.

—I am not sure whether Senator Haines is proposing $10,000 fines and imprisonment for five years for senders of junk mail, but to the extent that she is raising a serious point about appropriate further amendments to the Postal Services Act I simply say that she is referring to a matter that was raised, to my knowledge, by Mrs Darling, the honourable member for Lilley, in the context of a private member's Bill last year. —I should like a little clarification of a matter relating to an amendment moved a little earlier by Senator Haines.

—Senator Haines has not moved her amendment yet.
—The amendment foreshadowed by Senator Haines. I am not clear whether Senator Evans indicated in his response that he would do something.
—Senator Martin, I do not think you can discuss an amendment that Senator Haines has not yet moved. If she moves it, you may then discuss it. We are discussing the Bill as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, will it expedite matters if I move the amendment that I foreshadowed earlier, for the benefit of Senator Martin? She can then hear the Minister's response about whatever subsequent action will be taken.
