—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 55, Schedule 1, after amendment of the Wool Tax (Administration) Act 1964, add:
World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983
Section 3, after sub-section (4), insert the following sub-section-
'(5) For the purposes of the application of this Act in relation to the Northern Territory-
(a) a reference in this Act to a State shall be read as including a reference to the Northern Territory;
(b) a reference in this Act to a Territory shall be read as not including a reference to the Northern Territory; and
(c) a reference in this Act to the Premier of a State shall be read as including a reference to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been the subject of some discussion between Senator Haines and me since our exchange during the second reading debate. I think the situation is now much clarified; there was a degree of misunderstanding between us as to what was contemplated. What Senator Haines is seeking here to do is propose a really quite substantial and contentious amendment to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act which has just passed this Parliament a matter of days ago and has just, I believe, been proclaimed, and to do so in relation to the position of the Northern Territory. I indicated on behalf of the Government when that Bill was being debated that the Government was willing, at the time of the next round of miscellaneous statutory provision amendments, to consider one uncontroversial amendment to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act as it affected the Northern Territory-namely, an amendment to put the Northern Territory in the same position as the States for the purposes of establishing the composition of the proposed commissions of inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I did indicate very clearly that the Government's position was not one of support for this proposal now before us, which is to place the Northern Territory in the same position as a State in relation to all aspects of the application of the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. I explained in some detail at the time we were debating this legislation in the Committee stage why the Government took this view. I will endeavour to do so very much more briefly now because the reasons are already on the record.

The situation is that the way the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act is drafted it relies for its force and effect on a number of different heads of constitutional power. So far as the Northern Territory and the other Territories are concerned, the Act relies for its force and effect on section 122-the Territories power-of the Constitution. So far as the Act's application to the States is concerned, it relies on a miscellany of constitutional powers, including of course in particular the external affairs power. What would happen, were we now to insert in that Act the amendment proposed by Senator Haines, is that the Northern Territory would be treated for all purposes in the same way as the States. To the extent the Act was subsequently decided by the High Court of Australia to have no application to the States because the Commonwealth lacked the necessary degree of constitutional power, the result of Senator Haines's amendment being passed is that that Act would also necessarily be held to have no application to the Northern Territory.

In other words, the Commonwealth would have thrown away an undisputed head of power that it has in relation to the Territories by linking the position of the Northern Territory and the other Territories directly with that of the States. Although this Commonwealth Government, like its predecessor, is perfectly willing, for the purposes of the normal and ordinary application of Commonwealth legislation, to have the Northern Territory treated in the same way as the States, this Government, like its predecessor, is unwilling to throw away a head of constitutional power which it clearly has up its sleeve and which would ensure the application of legislation to the Territory in circumstances in which the validity of the legislation may be under some challenge or in some doubt. That is the reason why the Government is resisting an amendment in these terms. I think that is the position which was readily accepted by the Australian Democrats when this aspect of the Bill was being debated.

I will say, however, this: Since the Bill is now going across to the House of Representatives with at least one amendment there to be accomplished to it in relation to the Honey Industry Act, I believe that it may be possible for an amendment to be specifically drafted, in the 24 hours or so that we now have before the Bill is dealt with in the House of Representatives, specifically to accommodate the position of the Northern Territory in the way in which I indicated was non-contentious and in the way in which I indicated that the Government was prepared to accommodate the Northern Territory-to put it in the same position as the States for the purposes of the procedures under the Bill in relation to the compensation inquiries. If it is possible to get such provision drafted in the short time available, I will undertake here and now to seek to have that provision inserted when this matter is debated in the House of Representatives before it comes back here for final endorsement. I believe that will be enough to accommodate the position as it was explained to and accepted by the Democrats when the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill was being debated, and I hope that is the view that will be adopted here.

I shall add one further comment. I think it would be an unfortunate precedent if we were to use this clean-up Bill, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provision) Bill (No. 1), to be the focus for contentious matters about which there is disputation between the parties and to use it as a vehicle for re-running debates on other legislation which we may have completed. I think it would be a most unfortunate precedent to establish, to have this Bill used as a vehicle for debates on contentious matters, and it is certainly very contentious for the reasons of principle which I have explained if it stays in its present form. I hope that Senator Haines might be prepared in those circumstances to withdraw this very broad and sweeping amendment and to accept the Government's undertaking to do its level best to get a much more narrowly tailored amendment, which meets the main point the Democrats are trying to establish here, in place by the time the Bill comes back here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment which Senator Haines moved is, of course, an amendment which was moved by the Opposition last week in relation to the World Heritage Properties Conservation Bill, and I am not surprised that Senator Evans maintains his opposition to certain aspects of that amendment. SPEECH.PARA: Insofar as some parts of the Bill do, in a sense, discriminate against the Northern Territory we would be prepared at an appropriate time to formulate an amendment to cover that situation. He further said:
What I have in mind is that the Bill would be amended by a miscellaneous amendments provision in the latter part of this year to accommodate that contingency.
That is, the contingency of some matter arising during the recess. He went on:
In the event that the legislation had not gone through we would deal with the matter at Executive level in the way I have indicated. I give such an undertaking on behalf of the Government.

I seek the guidance of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) on how this would affect the operation of clause 15 which requires copies of proclamations to be laid before Parliament and relates to certain parliamentary activities. I expect that the amendment--
That was my amendment-

would have the effect of including the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly as one of the Houses of Parliament, and I would think that is a very significant matter for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept the force of what Senator Martin said. I had forgotten that a further provision was raised. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not so sure that I appreciate the language of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I accept his assurances with some hesitancy. I am happy at least in the knowledge that the moving of this particular amendment has inspired the Attorney-General, if not the Government, to act with some urgency on this matter. —Until otherwise persuaded. TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I suggest that the Bounty (Room Air Conditioners) Bill 1983 and the Bounty (Steel Products) Bill 1983 be dealt with cognately.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to debate these Bills cognately? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Bounty (Room Air Conditioners) Bill 1983 and the Bounty (Steel Products) Bill 1983 both arise out of matters which were dealt with originally by the former Government. I will deal with them very briefly and separately. The Bounty (Room Air Conditioners) Bill provides a bounty to enable the manufacturer of room air conditioners in Australia, Kelvinator Australia Ltd, to be able to undertake in regard to its processes certain renovations, introductions and innovations to make it more competitive. The problem, as found by the Temporary Assistance Authority report, was that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a growing price advantage over local production is the main reason for the increased share of the market taken by imported products. A further reason is that imported products have been updated and adapted to meet specialised requirements to a much greater extent than the local product.

It has been indicated to the Temporary Assistance Authority by the Australian manufacturer, Kelvinator, that it has investment plans involving an expenditure of $4m to enable it to compete with imports at current tariff levels. The company believes that it will be unlikely for this plan to proceed in the absence of temporary assistance. As part of this plan its product range would be redesigned, some technologies currently incorporated in imported room air conditioners would be introduced and the sources of inputs would be reassessed. Kelvinator estimated that its investment plan would not be completed until the middle of 1984. The proposal made by the Temporary Assistance Authority was for this bounty to be granted. It is at the rate of $60 per air conditioning unit not exceeding a certain size and $90 for the larger unit. That bounty should enable the company to engage in the capital expenditure plan to make its industry competitive. That recommendation was considered by the former Government and on 27 October 1982 it announced that it had accepted the recommendation. This Bill merely implements that recommendation and, not unnaturally, the Opposition will support the Bill.

The other Bill with which we are concerned deals with the bounty on certain steel products. Again, this is for short term bounty assistance to the industry which is producing certain high alloy steel products. This bounty was recommended by the Temporary Assistance Authority in its report of 23 December 1982. On 1 February 1983 the previous Government-that is the Liberal-National Party coalition Government-announced that it had accepted the Authority's recommendation and would introduce legislation to give effect to that. The Bill before the chamber this afternoon is in the terms of the report of the TAA, as accepted by the former Government, and in those circumstances is supported by the Opposition.

I will speak very briefly to the question of the steel industry and the problems which gave rise to the necessity for this legislation. I will refer, also briefly, to the doubts that have been raised recently in relation to the Government's attitude towards the steel industry. The Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the honourable member for Parramatta, Mr John Brown, speaking in the House of representatives on 12 May, stated:

This Government is firmly committed to maintaining a viable, internationally competitive steel industry, not just because of its importance to the Australian economy or its capacity to employ people, but for a few other reasons.
A little later he stated:
The importance of the steel industry to our national security and defence arrangements is paramount.
He also said:
We are moving very quickly to finalise our steel development plan by the end of June.
A little later he said:
The steel industry can look forward with confidence to the end of June, when our steel development plan will be announced.
Finally, he said:
Our prime objective will be to create the environment for Australian industry to return to its once highly efficient competitive position in the world's steel industry.

I imagine that those sorts of expressions of hopeful anticipation and wish would be commonly held on a bipartisan basis. It is for that reason that I was amazed to find in the economic statement last week one of the most vigorous attacks made on the steel industry that one could imagine. What we found was that something which was going to keep the steel industry fairly fully occupied for quite some time as well as playing a major part in the national development of Australia and the Northern Territory-that is, the Alice Springs to Darwin railway-has been effectively scrapped. What it boils down to is that the changed terms and conditions as imposed by the Government in the economic statement mean that there is no way, as Mr Everingham, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory has pointed out, that the Northern Territory could go ahead with funding what is now its required share of that development. That means that because there will be no railway there will be no steel production which would have been involved in the production of the rails. That means that the whole of the attitude of this Government towards the maintenance and development of the steel industry must be placed under the same very large question mark as must the adherence of this Government to the principles of the development of the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you did for over 50 years-the contribution you have made since 1911. You did nothing. You are selective in your facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, on behalf of the Government, I have a request for an amendment. I move:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 5, clause 3, line 4, insert 'for a purpose other than the removal of impurities from the ingot by the process known as electro-slag refining' after ' the ingot'.

However, it is intended that assistance should apply to products-mainly tool- steel bars-produced from a prescribed ingot after impurities have been removed by smelting and solidifying by an electro-slag refining procses. The purpose of this amendment is merely to put beyond doubt what products are eligible for receipt of the bounty. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill be debated cognately.
—Is there any objection? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is happy to have a cognate second reading debate on the two Bills and to follow the usual procedure thereafter. The Opposition welcomes these Bills, which relate to the Australian Broadcasting Commission, its structure and function. We have no problems with regard to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. We are glad it is being considered in a cognate debate. The provisions of the Bill, which it is unnecessary to describe here, are ones with which we do not disagree or argue.

SPEECH.PARA: This leaves the main Bill, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill, for consideration. I begin by saying that the Opposition welcomes this Bill. It is, in large, a consequence of initiatives which we began in government. The main elements of the Bill were introduced into the Parliament by us during 1982. A former Minister, Mr Staley, established the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in May 1979. The report of the Committee led to the suggestions for a major restructuring of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. A former Minister, the Right Honourable Ian Sinclair, had much of the carriage through the Cabinet and Cabinet committees of the considerations which led to this Bill. My former colleague, the Honourable Neil Brown when he was minister, produced the Bill which came before the Parliament in 1982. It was Mr Brown's ministerial statement in mid 1982 which identified the former Government's acceptance of many of the recommendations of the Dix Committee of Review and the former Government's desire to see many of those recommendations put in legislative form.

Because this Bill is so much the child of endeavours by the former Government, we will want to support, encourage and endorse the Government in its efforts to achieve a stronger national broadcasting service. Although some of the comments later might concentrate upon a few areas of difference, it is important to set down that that is being done in a context of broad agreement, support and a bipartisan desire to see some of the recommendations of the Dix Committee put into effect. We see many of those recommendations of the Committee headed by Mr Alex Dix as identifying and providing the basis for such a national broadcasting service.

It is appropriate to place on record our appreciation of the work which was done by Mr Dix and his co-workers on that Committee of Review. It was a daunting task which they undertook and they produced a report of distinction. They did so with expedition. I believe they have done a public service to a wide number of Australians by the way in which they approached their problems and by the recommendations which they produced.

Some of the main advantages which may flow from this Bill-some of the things which the ABC can expect to achieve as a result of the passage of this Bill-were set down in another place. The legislation will be modernised; the independence of the ABC will be strengthened; the charter setting out the functions and obligations of the ABC will be clear; the statutory recognition of Radio Australia and the ABC's television news services are set out in the Bill. The legislation sets out the duties of the Board and the Managing Director. There is a major upgrading of advisory mechanisms. There is provision for an Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council. There are provisions for similar councils in relation to States and Territories, or any region. The position of the chief executive of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, which will be called the Corporation, will be substantially upgraded. He will now exercise statutory authority. Those positive features of the legislation are ones which we endorse and with which we wish to be associated. Sadly, of course, today's debate might seem to suggest otherwise. The Opposition has several worries about the Bill. We and others will be moving amendments to various parts of the Bill. But we will be doing this against a background of support for and pleasure at the general package offered by the legislation.

I might set out the three areas in which we have some concerns. First, we believe that special circumstances now exist in which several issues of equity require some delay in the implementation of any restructuring of the Commission and its members. We recommend this so that those being sued now can be seen to be able to defend themselves against those legal actions. Our second area of concern is that we wish to see the provisions for withholding pay-admittedly as a last resort-in those circumstances in which officers refuse to work as directed retained in the legislation. The third area in which we have some concern is that we believe there should be some mechanism for resolving complaints, a mechanism which should be independent of the new Corporation and along the lines of the process which operates in the United Kingdom in relation to, say, the British Broadcasting Corporation. Although we have these three areas of concern, we accept much that is in the Bill and express our agreement and pleasure with much of what we read.

I turn to the first of the areas of concern. Special circumstances now exist, circumstances which could not have been anticipated and which we believe have created new responsibilities. I refer, of course, to the circumstances that have arisen out of the screening of a Four Corners program recently. Without trying to canvass matters which are sub judice or to anticipate any royal commission's findings, I think I can summarise these events: First, serious allegations were made in the ABC program about the administration of justice in New South Wales; secondly, several citizens of New South Wales have commenced defamation action as a result of that program being screened; thirdly a royal commission is now examining matters raised in that program; fourthly, the Premier of New South Wales has stood aside for the duration of the royal commission; and, fifthly- here I can be more specific-some of the Australian Labor Party Ministers of the present Government in Canberra have been vehemently critical of ABC commissioners following the screening of that Four Corners program.

For example, allegations of bias have been made against the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Commission by the Leader of the Government in the Senate , who is also the Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications. We have had the statement by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, in which he accused the ABC of selective broadcasting or of being anti-Labor. We have had the revelation that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when he was Leader of the Opposition, and Senator Button attempted unsuccessfully to influence the programming of the Australian Broadcasting Commission during the recent election campaign. None of this sequence of events could have been anticipated when the Bill was introduced. But the events raise serious questions which require consideration.

I ask honourable senators to consider the position of all the people who are affected by what has arisen. The question is: What course of action taken in dealing with this Bill is likely to be fairest to the three groups most at risk? What course of action is likely to be fairest to the Premier of New South Wales and to others, such as the magistrates, who were mentioned in the program? What course of action in relation to this Bill, in the light of the events that have occurred following the screening of that program, is likely to be fairest to the ABC commissioners? What course of action is likely to be fairest to the officers of the Australian Broadcasting Commission who researched and produced the program? I do not think they are irrelevant questions. I do not think they are easy to answer. The royal commission could go some of the way in answering those questions. But the resolution of issues which will come before a court when the civil actions for defamation are raised may well be an essential part of seeing justice done for all the parties.

Let me say that the Opposition has no argument with the proposal that the ABC should be restructured along the lines set out in this Bill. We proposed that last year. We have no reason not to want that to happen. But we believe that the commissioners who at present bear the responsibility for a program they allowed to be screened and whose reputations are in jeopardy right now should be the people who are allowed to see this issue carried through to resolution.

We know that the new board must accept the defamation actions which have begun. We know there are provisions in the second of the Bills which put that beyond doubt. But if the board of the Corporation is reconstituted with different people consider what will happen if they determine, in their wisdom, to settle the defamation cases out of court. The public will never know whether the settlement out of court was made on its merits or if it was made for other motives such as, perhaps, to hush up the matter. In those circumstances the new board of the Corporation may attract odium quite unreasonably, but people will not know. If the cases are settled the present commissioners will not have had an opportunity to present or defend a case in court. Instead, that will have been done for them by their successors. I think in those circumstances the reputations of the present commissioners would suffer without them having been able to have a hand in the defence of actions taken against the ABC, and their reputations would suffer unfairly. In fact, those who are now the subject of these actions may not have had sufficient opportunity to put their case before a court at all. The public will have been denied the opportunity to judge for itself what was right or wrong, where the balance of truth lay and where the merits of the matter were.

Now, consider the alternative-that the new Corporation with its new members does decide to defend the cases. Those whose reputations are at stake will still have no role in mounting or conducting the defence by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, as it will then be, of decisions which they took and for which the Corporation is being sued. Given the extraordinary circumstances that have arisen, if the present commissioners were allowed to see the matter through decisions in relation to the actions would be theirs. The principles behind the Bill would not be threatened or placed in jeopardy. In fact, an alternative might be to undertake to appoint the present commissioners for the duration of these legal actions. But because we are concerned about matters of equity to all the parties concerned in the issues that have been raised by this Four Corners program we are moving an amendment at the second reading stage. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with until-
(a) the legal action against the Australian Broadcasting Commission instituted by the Premier of New South Wales is concluded; and
(b) an assurance is given by the Government:
(i) that no action will be taken to alter the existing membership of the Commission until the Bill is again before the Parliament at the conclusion of those legal proceedings, and
(ii) that there will be no Government interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its programming policy'.

I commend the amendment to honourable senators as a genuine attempt to ensure that justice is the predominant thing we achieve while the ABC seeks to resolve the issues which arose out of the recent program. The amendment contains in paragraph (b) (ii) a rather more ominous component-an assurance that there will be no government interference with the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its programming policy. We thought it necessary to move this part of the amendment because of the events which occurred during the election. That Mr Hawke and Senator Button tried to intervene in the programming practices of the ABC during the election gives no cause for confidence about what the future holds. The events which unfolded in the Parliament as a result of questions asked here suggest clearly the need for the assurance sought in the last part of the second reading amendment. I ask honourable senators to read the answers to questions. I will not reiterate them now; they are on the public record. I ask honourable senators to look at what Ministers of this Government have been saying publicly. I ask then: Is it not reasonable to seek an assurance that the ABC will be independent of any attempt to influence its programming policy and of any attempt of the kind that was made during the election campaign ?

The Opposition will move some amendments also in the Committee stage and I will speak then to each of those amendments. It might suit the Senate at this stage, though, if I were to foreshadow the general areas in which those amendments will be moved. We will move in Committee an amendment to continue to enshrine the principle that in a situation where people refuse to work as directed, they should not be paid. At the Committee stage I will give the arguments which we believe would warrant support for that amendment. I understand that the Australian Democrats were concerned previously that any directions given in relation to the no work as directed, no pay question should be lawful directions . I indicate that we have added the word 'lawful' at an appropriate spot to make sure that we are proposing that no work as directed, no pay should apply only in relation to lawful directions. I hope the words proposed will cover the concern expressed by the Democrats.

Another area in relation to which we will be moving an amendment in Committee is a complaints commission. Here we have a very simple proposition. Many public organisations attract complaints. Some of the complaints are reasonable, some of them are frivolous; but there is always a problem of knowing whether they are seen to have been dealt with seriously. Justice is never seen to be done when an organisation investigates itself in response to public complaint. There is never satisfaction when the police investigate complaints against the police, or when a department is responsible for investigating complaints against that department . This is the reason that we have the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This is the reason that we have the Ombudsman. This is the reason that in the United Kingdom a British Broadcasting Corporation complaints commission was established .

At the Committee stage we will set out in detail our proposals in this area. The community affairs officers as proposed by the Government will go some way. Their appointment will establish an internal mechanism by which the ABC will look at complaints, but in no way can this be taken to be an adequate response to the need for an independent examination of serious complaints-not just because it concerns the ABC, but in the same way as any public body must be seen to deal with complaints in a way which is scrupulously fair.

I come back to where I began: The Opposition is delighted to see this Bill before the Senate. We are delighted in general by the changes which the Government has proposed. We are delighted and pleased that the Government has seen fit to pick up so many of the recommendations and proposals of the previous Government in relation to the ABC. We are delighted to see that the Dix Committee report is being translated in such a major way into legislation. We believe it will be good for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It will be good for the new Corporation and I believe it will be good for broadcasting in this country. I ask honourable senators to give careful consideration to our second reading amendment, and to understand that it is prompted by an attempt to see justice for all those involved in the affairs currently exercising our minds in New South Wales. I commend our amendment and the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Baume spent more than half of his speech re-running a matter which was dealt with in a matter of public importance a couple of weeks ago, and less than half of his speech discussing the actual Bill. I am not going to fall into that same error in dealing with a matter which was more appropriately dealt with on that previous occasion, not while the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill which restructures the Australian Broadcasting Commission is being debated. I think the Opposition is showing absolute hypocrisy in its attitude to the independence of the ABC. The sins of the Ministers which Senator Baume referred to, if they are sins, pale into insignificance when compared to the actual heavying-if I can use that word- of the ABC by Ministers of the previous Government over many years, of which Mr Nixon of the Country Party was the greatest exponent. Even in Opposition they tried massive intimidation of the ABC. It is the Australian Labor Party which consistently over many years has defended the ABC and its independence. The new- found support in the now Opposition for ABC independence is quite hollow.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill not only deals with the restructuring of the ABC but also defines its functions, powers and responsibilities. It is perhaps appropriate that the ABC, affectionately known to many people as Auntie, should be undergoing a mid-life crisis with this profound change in structure. As Senator Baume said, many aspects of the Bill are similar to those introduced by the previous Government, but there are significant changes. I think there is clear evidence that the ABC has undergone a hardening of the arteries over the years. The report by the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Dix report, stated:
The ABC has become slow-moving, over-grown, complacent and uncertain of the direction in which it is heading, despite the efforts of many talented and dedicated people who work for it.

I wish to put on record my appreciation of the services provided in the past by the ABC and of the influence which it has had on most Australians. I must say that I have a very proprietorial attitude to the ABC. I believe it is mine; it is owned by all of us individually and collectively. I think most of us have a dreadful love-hate relationship with the ABC. I certainly do. It has been an important part of my upbringing from as early as I can remember. Overall I think we can be proud of it. We can love it for its traditions, its ability to do things well, its reliability and the way it can make us proud of it and proud of Australia. In his commentary on the Dix report called 'The ABC After Dix', Senator Button said:
The ABC is a great national institution; it has been a vital part of Australia' s everyday cultural life since 1932.
Later, Senator Button said:
It has built up a faithful following over the 50 years of its existence.

I think the ABC can also be so very annoying when it does not live up to its potential, when it loses some of its best staff, when it does not do things as well as it could, when it is timid and apologetic, when there is excessive management intervention with programmers or when it responds too easily to overt political pressure especially, as I said earlier, from the National Party. The ABC is annoying to me also when it has unnecessary internal fights and bickering , the sort of unhealthy competition that sometimes occurs between news and public affairs sections, when it loses its traditional rights to televise cricket matches and other great national events without a sufficient battle and when it loses its current affairs leadership. The ABC can be so very annoying when its news service is not always as competent and reliable as it used to be and when it is clearly frustrating many of its talented and dedicated workers.

Unfortunately, in recent years it has lost much of its greatness. It has not demonstrated so much verve, adventurousness and confidence in itself. Since the high period for the ABC which I think was the 1972 to 1975 period of the previous Labor Government, under Ministers Douglas McClelland and Moss Cass, when there was proper encouragement, funding and freedom for the ABC, that institution has gone downhill. During that enlightened period from 1972 to 1975 morale was very high. There were new programming experiments and innovation in drama production. Where is that production now? That was the period when the go- ahead was given for radio station 2JJ as it then was-the go-ahead for FM transmission. Unfortunately, under the Fraser Government there were savage cut- backs in funding. An overall atmosphere of anti-public enterprise affected the ABC as it did other government institutions. While a little fat trimming can have a beneficial effect, wholesale amputations can have such a debilitating effect that any aims at improving efficiency are lost in low morale and internal dissension.

This legislation is intended to give new life to the ABC. But that new life will not happen just through a new Act of Parliament. There must also be the right environment. No amount of refurbished legislation can help if the organisation operates under an unsympathetic Government. That was the position with the previous Government. There are many improvements that one would like to see made to the ABC. I think one of the things that many of us would like is a second national television channel so that all sorts of national events can be televised without their interfering with the normal entertainment programming of the ABC. I think it would also be generally admitted that if there has to be a priority about this matter the higher priority is a second regional radio network so as to provide country listeners with a better service and the sort of choice that is available to those who live in the cities. Generally, sufficient funds need to be available to enable the ABC to regain its leadership. I am pleased that the Bill, as opposed to some suggestions made earlier, emphasises the ABC's continuing responsibility in the music field. I think it is important for it to maintain the symphony orchestras in each State. I think it is a great pity that the other musical enterprises that it used to have over the years have gradually been whittled away. I think those that remain ought to continue to be supported.

There is one aspect against which I want to speak out while we are debating this Bill. That is the question of television and radio licence fees which the present Chairman of the ABC has said she supports, I think on the basis that it would give the ABC more independence from government funding and provide a hedge against rising costs. I believe they are Professor Kramer's words. But what she overlooks is the irrelevance of licence fees when they existed. While they may have been provided for the ABC in the early years of its life they certainly were not in my memory. The money that was received from licence fees did not go to the ABC. The amount of the fees was not at all related to the ABC budget. They were just a government revenue raising matter, costly to raise at that. I believe that the previous Labor Government was correct in abolishing those licence fees. But even if there were to be a link between licence fees and the ABC's budget, if the licence fees were to be large enough for the ABC's budget-I doubt whether the amounts fixed would be acceptable to the public, let alone to those who have to implement them-there would still be a dependence on the Government legislation to keep those fees up to the needs of the ABC. I do not believe that that sort of independence which Professor Kramer suggested would arise from the reintroduction of the regressive tax that existed previously. Further, it would just make the ABC unpopular with the general public if it were seen as responsible for the licence fees. It would be especially unpopular with those who tended to use channels and radio stations other than the ABC. I do not think it would enhance the ABC's reputation.

One matter in relation to the Bill to which I object is the name change. We are changing the name of the ABC from the Australian Broadcasting Commission to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. This was an initiative of the previous Government in its Bill last year and I think it is unfortunate that we are continuing it in this Bill. I see no reason for it whatsoever. I have seen no explanation or reason put forward. It seems a wholly arbitrary change merely for the sake of making a change. Why call the ABC a corporation? It does not operate in the market place as does the Commonwealth Banking Corporation in money-making activities in competition with commercial operators. It just seems quite unnecessary. I suppose that the least we can be is thankful that the Dix Committee's recommendation that there be a complete name change to the National Broadcasting Organisation was rejected by the Government. I was critical last year of the previous Government for not bringing its Bill on for debate last year. It languished on the bottom of the Notice Paper for quite some time. But with hindsight I think we are lucky that it was not passed then in that form. If it had been we would be stuck with a less than satisfactory Act. The new Government has improved the Bill in many ways, especially in the areas in which the Opposition is now seeking to turn back to its previous provisions. I believe that the Bill deserves a speedy passage so that without any further delay the ABC can have its new charter and its new structure and get on with its job as all of us expect it to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill is essentially the creation of the Fraser Liberal Government. I say that not in any partisan fashion but to establish that the legislation is essentially bipartisan and most of it comes before the Senate supported in a bipartisan way. Well it should be supported in a bipartisan way if we are to set up the elements for the future of a national broadcasting system. Its genesis, of course, was the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, led by the distinguished Australian, Mr Alex Dix, and its report which, I think, had some 273 recommendations, many of which have been adopted and incorporated into this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is overdue. I say that not in criticism of either the Whitlam Government or the Fraser Government. I say it as one who, for some years, was privileged to be a member of a Senate standing committee which inquired over many lengthy hours and days into all aspects of broadcasting and television in Australia. That Committee revealed in various reports to this Senate a variety of apparent weaknesses in the national broadcasting structure. It became quite apparent that the Australian Broadcasting Commission was a body which was internally structured in a way that it could not fully discharge its duties. There were the limitations not only of money or of channels but also, fundamentally, of the internal staffing structure. So, it is important to look at this legislation not in terms of what broadcasting and television have been in the past but what they are likely to be in the future. This charter is not a charter for that limited number of radio and television stations that we have known.

Let me start by saying that television in Australia, and indeed in the world, is in its infancy. It is a new form of projection. Until now, in most countries it has depended upon the ether; it has depended upon using the various bands of the spectrum to get its message across. That in itself had two main limitations. The traffic in the spectrum-radio and television traffic-is intense for a variety of reasons. Of course television depended very much for direct sight signals over the area involved. A continent the size of Australia presents enormous problems in that regard. The result was that there has been, as I said not only because of money, a limitation in the ability to set put a number of channels.

That limitation in terms of technology is no longer with us, but in terms of economics it may well be. The fact of the matter is that we should look at this legislation not in terms of simply cable television as we have known it in the past or as we presently know it in Canada and America in a form of coaxial cable with 60 or 80 different channel facilities, but in terms of the new technology called fibre optics, which embodies the ability to send a laser beam down an optical fibre to every home, building and institution. That is the technology of the decades ahead. Such a signal which can be wired into any home, as it is being done at this moment in new towns in various parts of the world, using the ordinary wire carrying the telephone service into the home, can technically carry an infinity of signals either way, and so overcome the biggest problem of broadcasting and television; that is; the limitation of the spectrum.

One of the things that we have failed to do well in Australia-indeed the Senate has been a watchdog in this respect-has been the expert management of the spectrum. People cannot comprehend the spectrum. One of the most precious resources, and limited resources, that any country or the world has is the ether , the ability to control the amount of traffic in the various bands from the ultra high frequencies down to the lower frequencies and the ability to use it to its best advantage not only in civil pursuits but also in military and commercial activities. As the fibre optic technology develops, it will open a technological advantage which is wider and more challenging than perhaps is first thought. The very limitation of channels today, by the use of the ether, means that we have in any capital city three or four television stations all very similar in their nature and content and which have to compete with each other. They do not have the opportunity to diversify and there is no opportunity to specialise. We are looking at a charter which proposes the opening up a number of channels for all kinds of reasons-not just for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-and a future that has a satellite setup that, if it is proceeded with in the ordinary way, will give enormous extra opportunities to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and, I hope, to the commercial media.

Along with that, of course, another technology is developing. Instead of the videotape with which we are all fairly familiar now, the video long playing disc is coming. We are all used to the audio long playing record but today it is possible to mass produce, just as we produce excellence in sound by mass production, excellence in video. Just as today we can have excellence in high quality music through frequency modulation broadcasting, so tomorrow excellence will be established in a variety of ways. The capacity to store material-and to store it indefinitely-on what are virtually discs that cannot be damaged because they are scanned by laser, is immense and opens up a real breakthrough. Suddenly we are moving from the mediocre of today. There is such a limitation to production of quality programs at present that we tend to average out the product. Tomorrow, just as every family can have the best music in the world, so we will move into the television field as well.

I say those things not in some 1994 spectacle at all-not in some schoolboy ecstacy of what might happen-but to establish what is being proposed now because the charter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is meaningless if we talk about one channel. How in the name of fortune can we ask people to do all the things that they are expected to do given the fact that they have one channel and they probably have in a total of a seven-day week something less than 100 hours? How can employees at the ABC be innovative, provide a comprehensive service, maintain a high standard, look towards a balance between what the commercial stations do and what the ABC does, be educational, look towards the multicultural nature of Australia and look towards the whole spectrum of opportunities all in one channel and all perhaps in a transmission day of 14 hours or 15 hours? One has to say that it is an impossibility so to do.

I commend the charter. I understand the enormity of the difficulty of the Australian Broadcasting Commission today when it is torn between a competition for ratings and its overall task. Its employees ask: 'What is our job? Should we attract a larger percentage of viewers or should we do specialised programs?' I suggest to the Senate that in future a great deal of that torment may well be unnecessary because there ought to be the capacity for the individual to select from a range of programs. Once it is possible for the individual viewer or listener to be able to tune out of the mediocre and into the excellent, we will have an exciting situation. This is doubly so because we have lived with television only for a matter of a few decades. We have failed to understand the nature of television. Indeed, most of us in public life fail to understand that television sees more than it hears. It is compelling to the eyes more than to the ears. I suppose that is the experience of most members of parliament. That, of course, creates another challenge. How does one project educational programs in the best of all ways when it is the visual rather than the auditory aspect which is appealing?

I approach the subject in this way: I remind the Senate, as some honourable senators with long memories may know, that we were told of the limitations of radio back in 1971-72 when I was a relatively new senator. We were told that it was impossible to have more AM stations and certainly more FM stations because the spectrum would not permit it. We fought and brought in a report. The McLean Committee of Inquiry into Frequency Modulation was set up to investigate the position in Australia and a breakthrough was made. So in terms of a greater width of radio, FM stations, community stations, public broadcasting and ethnic broadcasting are very new. One should look at the charter in terms of the ability to use what could conveniently be called cable television plus satellites for a future coverage of immense potential for Australia. That is aspect number one.

Aspect number two has always been the crippling of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, by asking or demanding of it that its handling of its staff should be on a parallel with Public Service methods. That created an absolute paradox. How can an organisation, that has as one of its major activities the creative arts, have a Public Service approach? One can, perhaps, have an organised, professional, systematic, lifetime, career approach to the questions of administration and technical projection and to the planning of programs. But creativity is an entirely different thing. It has been necessary everywhere else in the world to give such organisations a much greater freedom, a freedom to move out into the community, to contract out and put people on short term contracts, so that there is a greater diversity of opportunity, a greater quality of programs. I cast no reflection at all upon any member of the ABC, past or present, because the limitations are there. They were put there by us.

If we can, as we are, I hope, doing, free the Australian Broadcasting Commission from the shackles of the rigidity of the Public Service, if we can give a management role to management-I interpolate here that the general managers of the past were not in effect really general managers because they did not have the same ability as a general manager in commerce or industry may have- then we will see greater opportunities for the staff to do their job and to do it well. I commend the ABC on its journey so far. Above everything it needs a freedom in the creative art to move across a much wider spectrum. So the very nature of the structure of staffing arrangements is important. I note in the speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) and in the explanatory notes to the Bill great emphasis has been put on the removal of the staff from Public Service shackles. I think that is of tremendous importance.

We are constantly talking about the need for independence. It is as though independence were a goal in itself, as though there was something very special about independence. Independence in a statutory corporation is a means to an end and not an end in itself. That is of tremendous importance. When we set up statutory corporations we say that we will free them from the duress or the direct or indirect influence of outsiders, be they political or otherwise. We give them that freedom but we do that as a means to an end. We do that as an environmental thing. The end in itself is the objectivity and the integrity of the organisation. They are the goals. The charter gets to the very heart of it. Again, I make no reflection upon any member of the ABC because I believe we have been well served. It is important that there be a goal of integrity, of objectivity.

We have in the past imposed enormous difficulties upon the ABC. I think the old broadcasting Act, if I remember it, talked about adequate and comprehensive programs. I think that was in section 116 or 117. What did we mean by adequate and comprehensive, when the staff of the ABC had, as I said, about 100 hours in a week in which to cover the whole of man's activities? What we are saying to the ABC is that we are going to try to establish in a statutory corporation freedom from duress, but that does not give it-it understands that-a form of liberty that approaches license. When one gives people freedom, fundamental to that freedom is the giving of a major responsibility. One is saying: 'I am giving you freedom so that your responsibility is to be objective. Above everything, your integrity is under test in that freedom. That is why we have given it to you'. That is very important, because time and again people look to the thought that freedom or independence is a goal. It is not at all in that regard.

Inevitably, we ought to create a system that is not free from criticism. One of the troubles of the past has been that the freedom to criticise our broadcasting system has been shackled, largely by the constraints of our own making in this kind of chamber. One heard it even today. What do we remind ourselves of? If somebody criticises something that happened in the past the retort is that one is trying to use duress; one is trying to pressurise. It is a sad thing indeed that we have stifled the free criticism of any organisation. We do not stifle criticism of the Dairy Marketing Board, the Peanut Marketing Board or any other statutory body that has been set up. In fact, we encourage criticism here, but we have a game, the rules of which I hope will be set aside after this body is set up. I hope that we will feel free, responsibly, on both sides, to criticise. After all, in the final result we are responsible for that statutory corporation . It ought to be capable of receiving the criticism of the world outside. Nobody is saying that if we do that it is bad, that we are trying to pressurise the organisation, or that we are trying to use undue influence. Of course, there was some reason behind that in the past. No doubt it has been tried.

I say that because I also want to make the point that there is a defect in this legislation. I refer to clause 82, relating to community affairs officers. Members of the existing staff and future staff of the ABC should never be frightened of public criticism. Such criticism should be part of the very atmosphere of democracy. Equally they should not be frightened of a system that hears complaints, examines them objectively and reports on them objectively.

In every State in the Commonwealth we have arguments from time to time about complaints against the police. We hear repeatedly that the police ought not to hear complaints against themselves and report on whether or not they were justified. I respect the integrity of the police forces overall in the States of the Commonwealth. The worst of all worlds will occur if we set up in this legislation a mechanism so that the only way in which complaints can be judged- only on a very narrow level-is by internal staff members of the Corporation receiving the complaints and reporting on them. That does not reflect at all on any future community affairs officers or the Principal Community Affairs Officer . Caesar cannot sit in judgment on Caesar.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might separate the wheat from the chaff.

—Yes. It is not a reflection on the person; it is a criticism of the system that makes that person's job absolutely impossible. If we proceed simply with this and nothing else the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will have more criticism and more complaints in the future-possibly some of them more justified-than in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what a complaint must be. First of all a written complaint which is made to the Corporation must allege one of two things-that an error of fact has occurred or that there has been an invasion of privacy. That is all. It cannot be a wider criticism. The astonishing thing is that this legislation states that the community affairs officer will examine the complaint and he can decide whether to reject it and not to investigate it on the ground that, in his opinion, it is frivolous or vexatious. I believe that it is totally unfair to that officer to say to him: 'It is your responsibility to judge that matter'. Every one of us, as members of parliament, has difficulty in deciding day after day whether a letter that comes across our desk or a telephone call borders on the frivolous or vexatious or whether we should take the matter more seriously.

Of course the officer has to make another decision-whether the complainant has sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint. Surely any citizen of Australia who, having paid his taxes, listens to or views a program, has an interest in the matter raised. Surely every citizen of Australia has an interest in the very nature of the national broadcasting and television service. I believe this provision in the Bill is a fundamental weakness. If the matter rests here we will have the worst of all worlds. The staff will receive complaints which many times will be entirely unjustifiable. Members of the public will say: 'This is no way to handle my complaints'. They will imply, probably wrongly, that the staff officer is protecting the staff. Why should the staff officer sit in judgment? He is an interested party; he is part of the organisation that is being criticised.

I cannot for the life of me understand why we cannot look at the British Broadcasting Corporation. It looked at the question of a complaints commission and decided that it was of such importance that it ought to have two very important elements. The first was that it should be independent of the British Broadcasting Corporation. The second element was that the complaints commissioner should be of such a stature and have such an intellectual capacity and respectability in the community that people would say: 'That complaints commission is doing an objective job'. The British Broadcasting Corporation appointed a former Lord Chief Justice to the job. It would not be a bad thing to look at that. The United Kingdom thought it was important to take complaints out of the Corporation after it initially looked at them. The United Kingdom thought the position of commissioner was of such importance that it should choose somebody of immense stature in the land to fill it.

How do we shape up to this situation? How are we creating independence and integrity? The test of independence is whether the Corporation can stand up to criticism and be judged. How is its independence and integrity tested? Will this be done by members of the Corporation? There is no magic in putting human beings in a statutory corporation. They are the same human beings whether they are inside or outside it. It is the responsibility that they bring to their judgments because of the freedom that they are given that is all important. If we are sincere in what we are saying in this legislation-that we want a corporation that is independent, has integrity and can give balanced programs-we must have some ability to test those programs and some recognition of the rights of people. For example, Mr Hawke and Senator Button should have the right to go to the Corporation, and the public should have the right to know that they have gone to it so that there can be no accusations of duress against them or, as in the past, Mr Nixon. On the surface the matter must be open and information must be available for everybody to see.

I plead with this Senate to take that dogfight out of politics and away from the pressurising of the community, and to set up a complaints commission which will decide whether, for example, Mr Hawke spoke too vigorously to the Chairman. Under this legislation the Managing Director and his staff, not the Board, decides whether or not a staff officer has properly disciplined another staff officer. That is an interesting situation. The management of staff is entirely under the Managing Director, so in future that contretemps could not occur. One would not go to one of the directors of the Board; one would go to the management.

We are setting up new legislation for the future, not for the complaints of the past. Let us look at it that way. Let us build into it the capacity to do the new things and to do them well, but above all let us put it beyond doubt that we mean it when we say: 'Let us give these people independence so that they can have integrity, adequate and innovative programming and so that there is no longer a dogfight inside or outside this Parliament on this matter'. Therefore, I urge honourable senators, when we come to the community affairs clauses, to look at an amendment that would establish a complaints commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Bill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill introduced by the Government. I was rather interested in the speech that has just been delivered by Senator Sir John Carrick. I found the first part of the speech interesting and absorbing when he talked about the technological future of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the possibilities of fibre optics and other means of public broadcasting and transmission. However, I must say I lost Senator Sir John Carrick towards the end of his address when he talked about a proposed complaints commission. What clearly came through from his remarks is that there is a need to provide for a method of dealing with complaints.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no argument about the fact that there needs to be a change, the difference between us is what form that change will take. I am encouraged that perhaps later, during the debate at the Committee stage, we might be able to deal with that matter more fully and perhaps assuage some of the fears that Senator Sir John Carrick has raised. It is perhaps inappropriate that these Bills are coming forward this year. Last year was Auntie's fiftieth anniversary. Perhaps we should have given her a new set of legislation to start on her next half-century of broadcasting in Australia. However, the Bill to amend the ABC last year was dropped down the notice paper and it befalls our lot, on her fifty -first anniversary, to try to refurbish the Commission and to give her a new direction and a new approach.

Any legislation dealing with the ABC does require considerable and close public scrutiny. The ABC is the only truly independent media outlet in Australia. For democracy to work, the people exercising democratic decision should be informed and have available to them a flow of information that is non-partisan and does not heavily favour one particular view. The ABC endeavours to provide that service which is vital to the continuance of there being an informed democracy in this country. We contrast the independence of the ABC to the other media outlets which are privately owned and which tend very heavily to be conservative in their expression of editorial view. It is legendary that the Murdoch Press tend to reflect the views of its owner, not to mention the rather gross exaggerations of the common popular Press.

The ABC has the obligation to remain truly independent and these Bills will provide the foundation for it to do so. The ABC is not only an outlet for news and current affairs. It is also a way of life for Australia. It is a means of entertainment, education, drama, music and ethnic affairs. It is a means of linking the city with the country and providing a homogenity of views for what is really the Australian personality. It is intolerable to imagine Australia without the ABC because the ABC really provides us with that extra dimension that makes us Australian. Unfortunately the ABC has a number of shortcomings. The Bill addresses itself to this fact following upon the Dix report by the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I will quote the summary of these shortcomigs of the ABC as they were found in the Dix report. Volume 1, paragraph 4 states by way of summary:

It has tried to maintain an idea of Australian society after that idea has undergone changes. Its energies have been sapped by often bitter industrial conflict. It has not only slipped from the forefront of change, but threatens to be eclipsed by it. The ABC has become slow-moving, overgrown, complacent, and uncertain of the direction in which it is leading, despite the efforts of many talented and dedicated people who work for it.

I think that is a fair summary of what has happened to the ABC. In the technical area, the ABC unfortunately shows, when held up in comparison to the commercial channels, many inadequacies. It is true that the commercial television channels display a greater technical competence than does the ABC. Increasingly, those commercial channels put to air news that is instantly recorded and transmitted into the middle of their bulletins by use of video materials, whereas the ABC has to close its deadline for news reporting on film because it shoots it in film, has to take it back to the studio and develop, cut and edit that film for presentation as a news service. I think it is intolerable that the ABC is in that competitive position where it is really not an adequate competitor for news . The ABC management must bear a large share of that blame. I do not believe that there are any insoluble demarcation problems within the ABC that an enlightened management could not deal with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use the opportunity of the adjournment debate to mention in the Senate a couple of matters that I have been unable to mention in any other way over the last few days. I mention the first matter now because I have not been able to ask a question in the Senate at Question Time over the last few sitting days. I am not particularly complaining about that, but there comes a time when eventually the subject matter of a question can get out of date unless something is done. I intend now to deal with the subject matter of the question I wished to ask. If honourable senators do not get an opportunity to ask a question during Question Time, primarily due to the length of answers by Ministers, they could ask the question that they wanted to ask in the adjournment debate. Perhaps we could have all the Ministers lined up in the chamber to take note of the questions that are asked which cannot be asked during Question Time.
—What a good idea.

—I think that would not be a bad idea because the questions are going very slowly. On this occasion I have not told the Minister concerned that I was going to speak but there certainly has been an attempt, I believe, to slow down the number of questions that are answered in this place.
—They're staying under cover. They're hiding.

—It could well be that they are hiding. I was going to ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) who represents the Minister for Aviation today whether he had seen a recent statement in the Australian by Mr Bryan Grey. He is the managing director of East-West Airlines Ltd. The article in the Australian of 4 May stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The political statements of the new Government indicate it is in favour of no- frills air fares. I believe--
This is Mr Grey's statement-

. . . that with two super 80s operating Melbourne-Perth on a daily basis, Brisbane-Townsville on a daily basis, and Brisbane-Sydney-Melbourne-Hobart, we could easily reduce the fare by one-third and still make a very handsome return on the operation.

Does the Minister agree that the airfare reductions are a most important matter not just for the people of Tasmania but really for the whole of the country? Will the Minister ask the Department of Aviation and the Independent Air Fares Committee to have discussions with East-West Airlines to do two things: Firstly, to facilitate the East-West initiatives and, secondly, to ask the other airlines why they cannot emulate the East-West fares? The Government has introduced two things that worry me. First of all, it is going to impose a 2c per litre additional duty on aviation spirit which will, in effect, impose a higher duty on it than on ordinary petrol. Ordinary petrol gives much more energy per litre than does an equivalent amount of the type of kerosene which is used in jet aircraft. I think that was an initiative that deserved a lot of commendation. The airline was flying full aircraft. Surely that is what an airline should be attempting to do. Actually, I flew in East-West Airlines' new F28 jet yesterday from Hobart to Sydney. It was just as good and as quick as some of the other jets in which I have travelled around the country. The jet has quite a lot of leg room. I commend it to those people who are flying from Hobart to Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —One class?

—I brought this matter up only because I have been trying for the last few days to ask a question. I have not been able to do so for one reason or another. Therefore, I am taking a little more time now than would have been available to me during Question Time.

—I am sure you do not need my assistance. You have obviously decided to proceed in this fashion.

—Perhaps the honourable senator is getting tired as the day goes on. The other matter about which I want to speak is coins. Over the years I have been attempting to get the Government to look at the whole issue of coins and notes throughout this country. I have gone back in my question file and I see that even as far back as 1972 I was attempting to get some alteration. Honourable senators have to remember that a lot of people collect coins, but not as many people collect coins as collect stamps. One person in six collects stamps and, I believe, one person in 12 collects coins.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1972 it was my idea to get the Royal Australian Mint to strike silver dollar coins that could be sold at a premium for collectors and also would enable the Mint to make some money. The Canadian mint makes quite a deal of money by producing dollar coins that are sold at a higher rate because of their silver content. Quite a profit is made. These coins are produced over almost an entire year. In 1973 I again tried to get the Government to examine the possibility of minting a $1 coin each year. Again no change was made. In 1976 it was pointed out that the cost of producing $1 notes in this country was quite high. By that time we had had a reasonable amount of inflation and it seemed to me that we should have not only a $1 coin but also other coins that might range as high as $5 or $10 in value. Not only do we need higher coin values-of course, that would need an alteration to the Currency Act because at the moment a 50c coin is the highest value coin allowed to be printed without any amendment to that Act-but also we should look at the size of all the coins in this country. Australian coins are exactly the same size as the coins that are used in Great Britain. In no other country in which I have been have I found coins that are as heavy, as expensive to produce or as annoying to carry as the ones that we now have in Australia. Our coins could be made of a different, low-cost material, something like copper or zinc, that would not be affected by world metal prices as are silver and gold.

While we are looking at this matter of coins-I believe it is under study by the Department of the Treasury at the moment-I suggest that the size of the coins should be very carefully chosen. Our 1c coin is exactly the same size as the American 10c coin. I think our 10c coin is the same size as the American 25c coin. That is a matter about which we should take a little more care. No two coins throughout the world should really be the same weight or size, for obvious reasons, in these days when machines are being used more and more as a means of dispensing all sorts of things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do we make them round?

—There is no real need for coins to be round; some coins are not round. Of course, coins go into machines a lot easier if they are round; they have to go through gauges to judge their size and so on. There are many areas in which coins could be changed not necessarily tomorrow but perhaps in Australia's two-hundredth year a coin design competition could be held. Perhaps we could have the Queen on one side of the coin and even the Prime Minister of the day on the other. A special coin could be struck every time there was an election.
—That would cause devaluation.
—I do not know. Some coins might only get struck once or twice and they would very quickly become collectors' items.
—The Hawke coin will be in small currency.

—I do not want to get into that. In Tasmania one can still buy petrol after hours using machines with note acceptors. These machines are not as reliable as coin acceptors. That is another reason why we need a higher value coin. Telecom Australia is having a lot of trouble at the moment with its green subscriber trunk dialling and international subscriber dialling telephones. The coin boxes are filling up too quickly and have to be cleared more often now that the cost of a call has gone up from 10c to 20c. It is practically impossible to make an ISA call using the coins that we now have. The rate at which one has to feed in the coins makes it almost impossible to concentrate on a call as one has to keep feeding the telephone with the odd-sided 50c pieces.

SPEECH.PARA: That is something which I think should be looked at immediately. It would save the Government money. I know that one of the arguments against it is that the Government says it will prove to people inflation is going on. People do not need a reduction in the size of coins to prove that inflation is going on. While the Government is looking at this whole matter perhaps it could decide whether we need the 1c or 2c pieces ever again.

There was one other thing that I thought might be a good idea. I remember when I was younger that we used to be able to put our silver coins in the Christmas pudding. The Mint might be able to bring out a special Christmas pudding set once every four or five years. It would bring back the damaged teeth that used to make the dentists smile in the years that I was a child.
