SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is International Women's Day for Disarmament. The women members of Federal Parliament, supported by many of their male colleagues, have joined the international expression of concern by our quiet contribution today. I thought I would take this opportunity to remind honourable senators of some of the facts that are easily overlooked or missed in the discussions about questions of nuclear disarmament. We are coming to the stage when man is spending a trillion dollars a year on military activities. We have already an arsenal of over 17,000 targeted strategic weapons that can destroy all global technology and perhaps the entire species. That is how many weapons we have stockpiled at this stage. While we also have a number of people concerned about various 'isms' around the world we do not yet have a similar concern about the well-being of our planet to anything like the same extent.

SPEECH.PARA: Rapid advances in technology make the weapons of today more dangerous to civilians than to the armed forces involved. In developing countries political processes are increasingly under military control and civil rights are widely violated. Whilst business in the military sector is booming, recession grips world markets. We have stifled economic growth, increasing unemployment and millions added to the number of impoverished, uneducated and underfed people in the world. In 32 countries governments spend more for military purposes than for education and health care combined. While nuclear missiles can go from Western Europe to Moscow in six minutes the average rural housewife in Africa must still walk several hours a day for her water supply. In the United States of America, the world's first super-power, one person in seven lives below the poverty threshold. In the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the world's second super- power-at least that is the current rating-the infant mortality rate is over twice the average for other developed countries. The family breadwinner in industrial countries works 1 1/2 weeks a year to pay for national military forces.

Through the growth of the peaceful atom, nuclear technology and expertise have spread widely. Bomb grade material has as well. The average commercial reactor yields about 500 lbs of plutonium a year as a by-product of its operations. Plutonium in waste fuel can be separated chemically and used to manufacture nuclear weapons. Counting all power reactors now in operation, the potential from this source alone is about 7,000 bombs a year. Peaceful facilities, therefore, provide a direct and potentially clandestine route to the proliferation of weapons. Throughout the production process there are also the associated dangers of theft, terrorism, release of radioactivity and sudden catastrophe. We have already had experiences that are, even now, documented. Also, I understand, catastrophes have happened in previous years that have not been documented. Finally, at the end of the process there is a legacy for future generations in the unsolved problem of dealing with the deadly nuclear waste generated by both peaceful and military uses. At the moment the use of nuclear energy in the United States is dying, not because of what it creates-not cheaper electricity-but because of its radioactive waste. In the case of plutonium 239 that waste will be toxic for over 200,000 years.

Technology and the weapons that it has created have clearly surpassed the concept of nuclear force as a means of deterring war. The jump from a deterrent against war to usable weapons of war is now a feature of nuclear strategy, particularly in the United States. It is used to justify further escalation in numbers and technology. It also greatly magnifies the risk that these weapons will be used and that nuclear war to extinction could happen. In summary, that $ 9 trillion spent for defence in the last decades appears to have diminished rather than strengthened world security. This involves the argument that if we have more and more weapons we will be more and more secure. An uncontrolled arms race threatens the safety of the very people it is intended to protect. At a time of grave economic social distress world wide there is nothing that is needed more for the health of all nations than an environment that is conducive to co-operation between countries. Instead, the dominating emphasis is on military rather than social threats to security and on military solutions to problems that, in fact, are deeply rooted in social conditions.

We need to consider who makes the decisions about military matters. Few people- I dare to wonder whether there are any women in such corporations or groups-in the military industrial complex are open to what one could say is community lobbying. In fact the very notion of members of the grass roots community telephoning their military industrial complex could be a farce. The really tragic point is that that is not possible and it is not even considered. In fact , if the idea is raised at all it is seen as a farce. In other words, the broad understanding of so many people in the world, that although they do not know the details, they are sure they do not want a nuclear war, never seems to penetrate the inner chambers where the military industrial complex makes its decisions. It would be a very unusual event if any of us got to know what arguments are used by these people. What are their terms of reference? What is the evidence they draw upon before they make their decisions?

In fact, because there is no way or only a minimal way of getting an input into the military industrial complex we can expect no change. One thing I would ask the Senate to consider seriously is the challenge of finding mechanisms for a grass roots comment to be taken seriously by such decision-makers and not dismissed as so much radical demonstration by yobbos or yahoos. People on the other side of those demonstrations say: 'There go the silly women and kids again '. Those demonstrators-those women and children-have a very powerful and heartfelt message that is never heard except by the media. It seems not be heeded by the decision-makers for nuclear development, particularly of the military sort. I think we have to consider mechanisms to bring about a change.

I think we have to find the political courage to redirect a percentage of that military expenditure from guns to butter. This is an old argument. I think it still has its credibility. If a very small percentage-some people would say one per cent and other people claim about 5 per cent-of money currently spent on military development around the world was redirected we could eliminate starvation from our world. That is not to say that we would solve all the social problems, but we would make a great step in that direction. Much of the campaign against nuclear weapons and their proliferation seems to many of us involved in it like so much hot air or barracking for the goodies. Nothing changes. We just keep saying the same things with bigger and bigger figures. My final word to this chamber tonight is that this situation must change-that is my passionate commitment and conviction-so that we never again see a military solution to a social problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few moments of the Senate's time tonight to talk about the savage attack on Queensland in the mini- Budget last week with respect to Brisbane Airport. Queensland is being plundered of far more than the $21m filched off the Brisbane Airport budget. Hundreds of jobs will be lost over this move directly and countless more jobs will be lost indirectly through the multiplier effect. Not one member of the Australian Labor Party is at all concerned about this, least of all its representatives from Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I admit to having a personal interest in both Brisbane Airport and the development of Townsville Airport. Long before I became a senator I did all I could to support the sterling work that was being done by Liberals such as Kevin Cairns, David Jull, Don Cameron and Peter Johnson and, of course, by senators such as Senator Martin, Senator Collard and the other senators for Queensland in what was then the Government who put everything into getting a new airport for Queensland. When I came along I gave them my full support. So it is a personal affront to me that this move should be made, quite apart from its enormous significance to Queensland and the Queensland economy.

I believe Townsville is going down the same path as Brisbane. I claim to have been the probable father of the development of Townsville Airport as an international airport, because after agitation on the subject I asked in the Senate a question which triggered the whole thing off. I asked why, since Qantas Airways Ltd was not prepared to operate out of Townsville, Trans Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia could not operate on a sector from Townsville through Singapore, Bangkok, and Manila to Fiji. That led to a proving flight from Townsville to Singapore by Ansett in March 1980. Of course, Qantas suddenly realised that there was no reason on earth why it could not operate through Townsville; and the rest is history.

I return to Brisbane Airport. In 1928 Kingsford-Smith landed there in a cow paddock. It was so wet there that by 1933 Qantas had transferred its operations to Archerfield, which was the main airport for Brisbane until the Second World War, when the Americans needed a second field; and from 1942 onwards the old cow paddock at Brisbane Airport was redeveloped. By the end of the 1960s it was apparent to Blind Freddie that we needed to so something about the enormous social disabilities we were suffering as a result of noise and air pollution from aircraft exhausts. Of course the State, under a free enterprise system, was burgeoning. A good airport is as essential for commerce and growth as a seaport was in the last century. The then Liberal Government in 1972 said: 'We will spend $1m in 1973-74, $13m in 1974-75 and $18m in 1975-76 and give Queensland the gateway to the world that it deserves'.

In 1972 the Whitlam Government was elected and it said: 'Certainly we will honour this promise'. In March 1973 the Cabinet rejected the funding for Brisbane Airport. By August 1973 it had thrown it out entirely and in mid-1975 it reaffirmed the decision to throw it out. In April 1976 the Bureau of Transport Economics report on Brisbane Airport recommended that the original proposal go ahead. In December 1977, $12m was committed, and on 5 June 1980 I had the pleasure of standing beside the then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, when the first sod was turned on the northern boundary of the new airport.

What happened after the 1983 election? Senator Kilgariff talked earlier about broken promises, and we have a classical broken promise with respect to Brisbane Airport. The Minister for Housing and Construction, Mr Hurford, went to Brisbane , puffed himself up and said-I quote him exactly:
Priority for funding the Brisbane Airport development would not be changed under the Labor Government.

The silly people of Brisbane believed him. What happens? We lose $20m of a $70m budget in the next financial year and $1m in the year after. That is about as far ahead as the Labor Party could look. This is not a small program. There are 350 people involved in it already and next year, 1984, there would have been 900 people involved. In 1980 prices it was a $300m development.

The Liberal-National Party Government got this project going. Labor came along, implacably opposed to Queensland, and cancelled the program. Let us not beat around the bush with words. This is what it is all about: Brisbane Airport is dead until we get a Liberal-National Party Government back, which means a delay of a year to a year and a half in the completion of this airport. The cost to Brisbane of these deferments is very severe. Unemployment is the biggest single issue in the country today. Here we have a $300m program employing 900 people next year. What happens? It gets chopped for a Mickey Mouse proposal to build a few houses and get a few short term, six-month Regional Employment Development Scheme type jobs. That is a great consolation for the hundreds of men and women in Brisbane who will be out of work because of the lack of foresight, the lack of understanding and the rabid anti-Queenslandism of this southern, centralist, socialist Government.

What about the social consequences? The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) is always bleating about the social consequences of noise on the residents. The shattering noise of 727s climbing over the city on full power will remain day and night, apart from the curfew hours, because there is no way in which it will be alleviated. The new airport would have alleviated it. But that is lost in nirvana now, in Never Never Land. What about the growth of tourism for Queensland? That has had the axe put through it. What about the commercial development that is going on? The net result is that we have been robbed of jobs and of essential growth in the economy of the State.

What is the response from the Australian Labor Party? I have already mentioned the honourable member for Lilley. Last Friday she was reported in the Press as saying that it was justified to cut $21m in two years from the Brisbane Airport budget. She said that it was justified because there will be houses for the poor and because it is not for the rich to fly around Australia. No wonder she has become a figure of ridicule not only in her own electorate but in the whole of the State. How much of the $21m that has been chopped will provide housing for the poor in her electorate of Lilley? There is no difficulty about housing in Brisbane. There is no trouble in buying houses. One can buy as many as one likes .

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have a job.

—The Government is going to cut jobs out; so that answers the honourable senator's question. There is no trouble in getting bank finance. The difficulty is in the ability to pay interest. Of course, one of the Government's programs-I will not enlarge on it-will put up interest payments by 1.5 per cent at least in the short term and drive people into welfare housing.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to Brisbane Airport. How much of the $20m will be spent in Lilley? I will tell the Senate: Hardly any at all. How many jobs will be created? How many people will be mowing footpaths and digging holes for other people to fill in? What consolation is it to people that they have lost solid jobs lasting for probably four or five years for some fanciful social theory of an academic government? What about other Labor members who are involved? What have we heard from the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh) and the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross)?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—As Senator Collard said, nothing at all. What have we heard from honourable senators? Except that they fly out of it when they come to Canberra, they would not know that Brisbane Airport exists. What do they care about it? Nothing at all. No section of the Australian community in a geographic sense has had to make the sacrifices that the electorate of Lilley, the city of Brisbane and the State of Queensland have had to make for this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to follow my colleague Senator Crowley in speaking here this evening to mark International Women's Day for Disarmament. I commend the efforts of all those women throughout Australia who have joined with women across the world to highlight our grave concern about the nuclear arms race and the threat to world peace. I mention particularly the outstanding and truly remarkable efforts of the women of Greenham Common. Last December 30,000 women from the United Kingdom and Europe linked arms around the base in an unprecedented demonstration of protest against the proposed Cruise missile base to be sited there this December . The peace movement has burst into new life. In the last three years it has swept through northern Europe and the United Kingdom bringing together in a broad coalition such diverse groups as environmentalists, radical Christians, the women's movement, trade unionists and other parties.
—Fellow travellers too; don't leave them out.
—It is a pity that the honourable senator does not join.
—I am not a fellow traveller, so I can't.

—That is quite obvious. The movement has gained sufficient momentum to make governments uneasy and to put disarmament back on the political agenda for the first time since the late 1950s. The adoption at the British Labour Party Conference of a policy of unilateral nuclear disarmanent is the clearest indication yet of the peace movement's new-found potency. The sources of European anxiety are not hard to find. The stable strategic situation of the 1960s and the early 1970s has been unsettled by the great improvement, if you can call it that, in the reliability and accuracy of submarine launched missiles which give them a first strike capacity and the introduction into Europe of intermediate range missiles which significantly reduce the warning time of an incoming attack. The fuse has become shorter with each technical improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: Strategic doctrine has also undergone change from the days when it was assumed that mutually assured destruction would promote great power caution and underwrite detente. TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley and Senator Reynolds have tonight expressed very worthwhile sentiments in relation to peace and disarmament to which I am sure no one can take exception. I look forward to the time when they are able to give us a more detailed plan on how these objectives might be achieved. I am very disappointed that Senator Reynolds did not respond to Senator MacGibbon's statements about Brisbane Airport. I remind Senator Reynolds that she is not just a senator for Townsville or north Queensland; she is a senator for Queensland as a whole. As a Government senator for Queensland she will have to have some answers on the subject of the Government's actions in relation to Brisbane Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: The airport decision has been cynical in the extreme. I notice Senator Giles having a little giggle. I did not catch the comment that preceded it. I also noticed that she was doing quite a deal of chattering in a rather loud voice while Senator MacGibbon was speaking. I appreciate Senator Giles's presence here but I say to her that this is a major issue not just for Brisbane but for Queensland. The Government's bona fides on this subject are totally at stake in Queensland and it just cannot expect to have the matter brushed aside. As I have said, the decision on Brisbane Airport was cynical in the extreme. It has been interesting in the last four days since the statement on this matter last Thursday night to note the reactions of Labor parliamentarians from Queensland on the subject. Senator MacGibbon mentioned Mrs Darling. Mrs Darling was quoted in the Brisbane Press last Friday as having said:
People who have neither houses nor jobs are never going . . . to fly in aircraft.

That is one of the statements that gave Senator Giles some entertainment while Senator MacGibbon was speaking. It is a fatuous statement which is just meant as a smokescreen. Our concern at this cut in relation to Brisbane Airport does not relate to people flying an aircraft, which is an issue that will come up in several years, but to the people who would have had jobs and who will not have jobs and to the people who might have been able to afford a house and who will not be able to afford a house because of this specific cut. I look forward to hearing what Senator Ryan has to say on behalf of the Government and how it justifies taking $20m out of what was a job creation project in itself under the Fraser Government. One can only speculate on the issue that has been raised previously. That is that Queensland has, for all its Labor parliamentarians in the national Parliament, only one person in the Hawke Ministry. That is Mr Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. He was overseas until last week. If he tried to have any effect on that decision it obviously was not very much effect. I think Mr Hayden, because he has been through this issue in several election campaigns in Queensland, would have had a better appreciation than is evidenced by this statement of what the actual implications were.

What of the Queensland Labor Party? What has it had to say? The Queensland Labor Party's recent statements on unemployment have a hollow ring in the wake of the Hawke Government's mini-Budget last week. Its leader, Mr Wright, has been grandstanding on Queensland's unemployment rate as part of the Australian Labor Party's campaign for this year's State election. He has, however, been strangely silent on the effect the Hawke Government's decision to reduce spending on the Brisbane Airport by $20m will have on jobs in Queensland; not on plane passengers but on jobs. That $20m represents a lot of jobs on the Brisbane Airport construction site, as outlined in detail by Senator MacGibbon. The money will go instead towards the Government's scheme to create jobs which will last, on average, according to the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), for only six months.

One has to ask how much the Federal Labor Government cares about unemployment in Queensland when it reduces employment possibilities on a major airport project in favour of an ephemeral, short term scheme which will probably be of only limited benefit to the State. I ask the tough political question: Does the Labor Party have a short term political interest in increasing the rate of unemployment in Queensland? It will be interesting to see in the next few months just how much Queensland benefits from other schemes in terms of job creation, having had $20m worth of jobs, and several hundred jobs, as indicated by Senator MacGibbon, lost through this one stroke.

I refer again to Mrs Darling. She said in her statement reported in the Press last week that she had fought for the airport for years. It probably feels like years because she has had a lot to say about the airport, but I remind the Senate of a few facts. Mrs Darling was elected in 1980. She has been a member of parliament for fewer than three years, although it feels longer. The Fraser Government was committed-fully com- mitted-to the present airport development program before the 1977 election. That was three years before Mrs Darling was elected. Three years before she became a member of parliament we had a commitment, and the project was under way. Less than three years after she got here, the project has been slowed down and possibly phased out. I wish her luck. I hope she has some effect on the Government in this fight she has ahead of her. She has obviously had no effect on this Government so far. In its desperate and largely futile efforts to find ways of reducing government expenditure, the Hawke Cabinet clearly saw a scaling down of plans for Brisbane Airport's redevelopment as one of its easier options.

Queenslanders must regard with some cynicism Mr Keating's bland assertion that this decision will not affect the airport's completion date. Personally, I think it is the thin edge of the wedge. If it has been so easy to slice off $20m and hundreds of jobs at this sort of distance, it will be easy and tempting to start winding the operation down. If the Labor Government does that, it will do so at its peril. Certainly, the newly elected honourable member for Bowman (Mr Keogh), the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Cross), the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humph- reys) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) will be delivered a very sharp rebuke by their electors on the issue of the priority of the project and by Queenslanders in particular for taking away $20m in solid jobs on a good construction project in favour of a vague six month only make jobs program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does section 39A (1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 enable members of the defence forces who are on service outside Australia to vote in an election.

(2) Does section 39A (2) of the Act extend this concession to dependants of members of the defence forces on service outside Australia; if not, does this mean that nearly 2,000 women are disenfranchised and will the Special Minister of State take the necessary action to remedy this situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes-Section 39A (1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act protects the voting rights of service personnel posted overseas. The provisions of section 39A (1) must be viewed in the overall context of enrolment and voting rights of electors who leave Australia. Generally speaking, when electors go overseas without intending to return to live at the address for which they are enrolled, they lose their enrolement entitlement after an absence of one month. In accordance with the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, action is then taken to remove their names from the roll. These persons cannot re-enrol until they return to Australia and fulfil the requirement of one month's residence in the subdivision for which they wish to enrol. This is the case for all Australians who are overseas, including Defence Force personnel.

If members of the Defence Force lose their entitlement to enrol when posted overseas, under section 39A they retain their right to vote as if they were enrolled for the subdivision in which they ordinarily lived immediately prior to leaving Australia.

(2) Section 39A (2) extends this protection to persons accompanying a part of the Defence Force in an official capacity. This section applies to persons such as officers of the YMCA and similar organisations and to accredited war correspondents, but does not cover wives and dependants who accompany service personnel, rather than a part of the Defence Force as such, to overseas postings .

Wives and dependants of service personnel are in the same position as other civilians who are overseas on the occasion of an election. If they are enrolled and have a fixed intention of returning to live at the address for which they are enrolled they are entitled to a postal vote. If not, they are not qualified or entitled to vote.

Changes to the voting rights of the dependants of overseas Defence Force personnel are among a wide range of matters which I anticipate will be investigated by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The Government will be looking at the question in the course of its consideration of the Committee's report.
